urn:contentItem:4S6G-XFX0-TX5N-015T-00000-00Ranger diary2008-04-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisTODAYPg. 53Ranger diaryCompiled by the Environmental Protection Agency.

CAMPING: Autumn is the perfect time to camp and enjoy cooler nights and warm days. Book now for the holidays at www.qld.gov.au/camping or 131 304. Visitors to Fraser Island must be aware of dingoes and need to keep a very careful watch on children and young teens -- never let them play or walk unsupervised. At Carnarvon National Park, access to the Gorge section day use area is open to all vehicles. The Amphitheatre remains closed. At the Mt Moffatt section, Dargonelly Rock Hole and Top Moffatt camping areas are both open. At Wongi State Forest, fire restrictions mean you must bring a gas or fuel stove. Diamantina National Park is open. Use caution when crossing floodways and travelling around the park due to damage from recent floods.

What's on: Lots of Go Bush activities are on offer during the school holidays. Learn about the amazing history of the Glass House Mountains next Wednesday. Join a ranger to walk around the base of Mt Tibrogargan and appreciate its beauty and heritage. On Thursday, discover the wonderful world of dragons and dinosaurs at Daisy Hill Conservation Park. Children even get to make a fossil. Or join the popular ranger-for-a-day holiday workshop at David Fleay Wildlife Park at West Burleigh. Cost is $35 a child and includes park entry, all activities, a photograph with an animal and a certificate. Book on 5576 2411. Check out the centenary of national parks historical exhibition at the Queensland Museum until April 27. It showcases memorabilia from the past 100 years, interactive displays and a documentary. Since the first national park was declared in 1908, Queensland's park estate has grown to 282 national parks from desert to rainforest to reef.

News: At Kenilworth Forest Reserve, the Bundaroo Creek bridge is closed to all traffic for maintenance. Forest Drive is closed from Funnels Hut Rd to Booloumba Creek. Access to Booloumba Falls and Booloumba View lookout remains open via Booloumba Creek Rd. At Molle Islands National Park, the walking track between Sandy Bay and Mt Jeffreys' intersection is closed for maintenance. Contact EPA Whitsundays on 4967 7355 for track updates. A feral pig was recently sighted on Long Island. Feral pigs can be aggressive and visitors should walk in groups, stay on the track and supervise children.

Wildlife: Snakes are still active this time of year. Clearing debris, wood piles, long grass and loose leaf piles can minimise places for snakes to hide in your back yard.

Compiled by the Environmental Protection Agency.

urn:contentItem:5T04-0VY1-F0NT-H31V-00000-00ASIC granted new powers over big banks2018-08-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisASIC granted new powers over big banksCrikeyABSTRACT

Good morning, early birds.

FULL TEXT

'CORPORATE COPS'

The Australian Securities and Investments Commission will for the first time be able to embed staff into the big four banks and wealth manager AMP, as part of a new supervisory "refocus" and budget boost to monitor governance and compliance.

The ABC reports that ASIC chairman James Shipton will today announce more than $70 million in additional funding and extended powers at a press conference with Treasurer Scott Morrison and Financial Services Minister Kelly O'Dwyer. The announcement follows Shipton's review into the organisation, which came under severe criticism at the financial services royal commission, as well as accusations that AMP charges fees for no service and has lied to ASIC.

Elsewhere, The Australian($) reports that the latest round of the royal commission has heard that super fund trustees are "surrounded by temptation" to do the wrong thing, and gouge customers with fees. 

PARTING SHOTS

Australia's outgoing public service and race discrimination commissioners have delivered fiery, but very different, valedictory speeches ahead of their official retirements.

The Age reports that outgoing public service commissioner John Lloyd has hit out at "political correctness" and having to leave under an unfinished, "most unsatisfactory investigation" into his connection with right-wing think tank the Institute of Public Affairs. Lloyd also made light of his   controversial connection to the group, and further criticised the state of Australia's workplace laws and alleged dwindling capacity to question authority.

Race discrimination commissioner Dr Tim Soutphommasane declared that "race politics is back" in a speech criticising politicians and journalists for escalating dialogue over "African gangs", ethnic separatism and immigration. Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs Minister Alan Tudge has    slammed the speech ($), which singled the MP out for warning that Australia is headed towards "a European separatist multicultural model".

INFOWARS IN THE BIN

Infowars' Alex Jones has had four pages shut down by Facebook and most of the group's podcasts removed by Apple and Spotify. The Guardian reports that Jones, a conspiracy theorist who is being sued by parents of children murdered in the 2012 Sandy Hook massacre for alleging the shooting was a hoax, has had his pages shut down just hours after Apple ditched five of the six Infowars podcasts.

Facebook had previously issued Jones a personal, 30-day suspension and has since said that, "More content from the same pages has been reported to us - upon review, we have taken it down for glorifying violence, which violates our graphic violence policy, and using dehumanising language to describe people who are transgender, Muslims and immigrants, which violates our hate speech policies".

THEY REALLY SAID THAT?

You have to make a decision about do you want an agriculture sector or do you want kumbaya?

David Littleproud

The Agriculture Minister has a go at state and territory governments for finding "some frog or butterfly" to delay dams and water infrastructure, and is rewarded with both heckles and applause from Lismore residents on Q&A.

"Sky News' decision to provide an uncritical platform for violent racist and convicted criminal Blair Cottrell yesterday, and its legitimisation of him as an 'activist', not merely continues the pay TV outlet's love affair with far-right extremists but will deeply concern Australia's security and intelligence agencies."

https://www.crikey.com.au/2018/08/06/poll-bludger-coalition-mixed-signals/   Poll Bludger: mixed signals as Coalition tries to turn the ship aroundWilliam Bowe

"As luck would have it, Malcolm Turnbull's reverse at the Super Saturday byelections landed just as opinion polls started pointing out a potential path to his re-election.

Not that the government is there yet. Its famous losing run in Newspoll extended to 37 last week, and no other established pollster has run a poll that failed to credit Labor with a two-party lead throughout this period, which began shortly after the 2016 election."

https://www.crikey.com.au/2018/08/06/sky-news-no-stranger-to-extremists-and-white-nationalists/   Sky News no stranger to extremists and white nationalistsCharlie Lewis

"Sky News has been dragged over the coals on social media for its Sunday interview with bulging fascist Blair Cottrell, with news director Greg Byrne saying the interview was 'wrong'. But is programming aggressive nationalist views really a departure compared to some recent Sky offerings?"

READ ALL ABOUT IT

'I wanted to go': Barnaby Joyce, the 'half-crazed cattle dog'

SEQ begins big push for a billion-dollar City Deal

First WA women's 'drug rehab prison' opens in Perth's south

If other countries knew how Australia stops the boats it could damage foreign relations, Peter Dutton told

Ex-Chief Marshall Perron to back assisted deaths ($)

SA Health brings in advisers KordaMentha to tackle $250 million debt from new RAH ($)

Stock market the biggest obstacle to finding dark matter down a mine

Government urged to dump 'flawed' health insurance discount plan for young people

Labor MP backs NEG with new coal plants ($)

Indonesia earthquake: at least 98 dead after quake strikes Lombok

Italy highway explosion causes fatalities and dozens of injuries

WHAT'S ON TODAY

Melbourne

Witnesses from NAB and its superannuation trustee will give evidence at a financial services royal commission hearing on superannuation. Ian Silk, the CEO of AustralianSuper, may also begin his evidence late this afternoon.

A Senate Committee will hold an inquiry into Australia's "obesity epidemic".

CFA Chief Officer Steve Warrington, Forest Fire Management Victoria Acting Deputy Chief David Sayce and Parks Victoria Director Fire and Emergency Services David Nugent will speak about emergency services personnel heading to Canada to assist firefighting efforts.

National, Liberal and Shooters, Fishers and Farmers MPs and MLCs will deliver a petition calling on more support for Victorian timber industry jobs.

Farmers, fruit and vegetable growers, wine and cheese makers, brewers, tourism operators, and apprentice chefs will meet at the steps of parliament to launch the campaign "A taste of Mornington Peninsula", which aims to raise awareness over the green wedge, to be followed by a tasting session in the Federation Room.

Sydney

A House Standing Committee will conduct an inquiry into funding Australian research.

The Reserve Bank of Australia will make an announcement on interest rates.

Lord Mayor Clover Moore and NSW Governor David Hurley will announce a major new public artwork to honour the First Peoples of Sydney and pay tribute to the traditional custodians of Gadigal Country. A performance by the Buuja Buuja Butterfly Dance group, a smoking ceremony and a Welcome to Country will be held at the beginning of the event.

David Gonski, UOW Chancellor Jillian Broadbent, UTS Vice-Chancellor Attila Brungs, and Macquarie University Vice-Chancellor Bruce Dowton will speak at an event on future-proofing Australia's workforce.

Former PM John Howard will speak at Campion College for the official opening of two new residential halls. 

Alinta CEO Jeff Dimery and Ausgrid CEO Richard Gross will speak at a CEDA event on consumers and affordability in Australia's energy market.

Canberra

A House Standing Committee will hold an inquiry into impediments to business investment. Three Senate Committees will also conduct inquiries into Private Health Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill 2018 and related bills; Social Services Legislation Amendment (Cashless Debit Card Trial Expansion) Bill 2018; and the prevention, investigation and prosecution of industrial deaths in Australia.

The Australian National University will hold an event celebrating the 50th anniversary of the Pacific Manuscripts Bureau.

Professor of Socio-Technical Innovation at UK's Newcastle UniversityMark Reed will speak at a Climate Change Institute presentation on "When Science Changes Society: When and How Research has Impact", to be followed by a panel discussion.

Brisbane

Former High Court Chief Justice and human rights advocate Michael Kirby will speak on LGBTIQ rights and the Catholic Church for the annual Archbishop Sir James Duhig Memorial Lecture, to be held at the University of Queensland.

The Queensland Sentencing Advisory Council will hold a panel discussion on "Expanding the toolbox: sentencing reform across Australia".

The Department of Transport and Main Roads will hold a statewide industry briefing.

Goorie novelist, essayist and poet Melissa Lucashenko will speak as part of Tony Albert's "Pay Attention" talk series at QAGOMA.

Darwin

The Civil Aviation Authority will conduct flightpath safety checks at 12 Northern Territory airports over the next week.

The Museum and Art Gallery of the Northern Territory will hold a preview of the 35th Telstra National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art Awards.

Adelaide

Raising the Bar will hold 20 expert talks across ten pubs in one night.

Perth

The Wheatbelt Development Commission will host the WA Industry Link Regional Roadshow, to include a discussion on the development and implementation of the Western Australian Industry Participation Strategy, amongst other initiatives.

Social innovator Karen Wellington will speak on "Sensing our emerging future in education" at an EDfutures community event. 

Hobart

Author Greg Lehman will speak on research into colonial representations of Indigenous Tasmanians through artwork, work which has resulted in the recently-opened National Gallery of Australia exhibition, The National Picture: the art of Tasmania's Black War.

Author and historical researcher Maree Ring will discuss "Military Pensioners to Van Diemen's Land 1850 - 1852" as part of a National Family History Month event at Hobart Library.

Australia

Australia's population is estimated to pass the 25 million mark around 11pm AEST tonight.

New Delhi, India

An extradition hearing will be held for Puneet Puneet, who fled Australia after pleading guilty to a hit-run fatality.

THE COMMENTARIAT

Why I quit Sky News over the Blair Cottrell neo-Nazi interview ($) - Dr Craig Emerson(Australian Financial Review): "On Monday I quit Sky News after five years as a commentator. Giving airtime to neo-Nazi Blair Cottrell might be passed off as defending the right to free speech, but former chief minister of the Northern Territory, Adam Giles, was effusive in his praise, wrapping up the interview with: 'Good luck. I hope it all goes well for you.' A Sky anchor wishing a neo-Nazi all the best in his endeavours is yet another step in the mainstreaming of racism and bigotry in our country."

How to catch a regulator - Stephen Bartos (The Age): "The banking royal commission has important lessons for all regulators, not only those concerned with banking and finance. As we now know from the commission's work, examples of bad practice are rife among financial institutions. They include overcharging or outright defrauding of customers, misleading advice, exploiting vulnerable Australians and other misdeeds. Even if financial institutions (mostly) do look after their customers, the commission is inquiring into misconduct - and finding plenty. The question for regulators is how this blatant and harmful misconduct can happen, and why it appears so widespread."

HOLD THE FRONT PAGE

urn:contentItem:5JT0-WHP1-DY19-C3Y6-00000-00When should we worry about climate change?2016-05-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisWhen should we worry about climate change?Peter Hannam, Environment editor

News that Tasmania's Cape Grim weather site had recorded its first baseline reading of 400 parts per million of carbon dioxide sparked some debate over the meaning of the milestone.

As we noted ahead of the declaration of the first recording of 400ppm in the southern hemisphere, the primary greenhouse gas increase carried not much more global warming significance than, say, 399 or 401 ppm.

"People react to these things when they see thresholds crossed," David Etheridge, a CSIRO principal research scientist, told us, perhaps a little optimistically.

Even more upbeat was Paul Fraser, the CSIRO scientist who had helped set up Cape Grim 40 years ago. He told 9news.com.au that passing the landmark would be a "psychological tipping point".

Other warning signs - such as the 1 degree warming point reached last year - did at least spur nations to agree at the Paris Climate Summit that temperature increases should be limited to 1.5-2 degrees, even if national policies made 3 degrees more likely.

And so, with CO2 concentrations marching past 400 ppm, when should we start worrying about global warming?

Does 400 ppm means we should start worrying now or when should we have started?

"About 30 years ago," is the blunt answer from David Karoly, a climate scientist with Melbourne University.

"But we shouldn't give up, either," he told me this week. "The worry - and the [climate] action - should now be increased."

Worries mount

There's certainly a lot to be concerned about in 2016.

Each of the last 12 months is now the hottest on record for that month, with April adding the recent string of beating-by-biggest-margin months.

(See NASA's chart showing temperatures were 1.11 degrees warmer than the 1951-80 average, with large areas in the north particularly warm, while Australia had its second-warmest April.)

Among the climate-related threats, Canada's forest fire season started about a month early. One huge blaze near Alberta's tar sands forced the evacuation of about 88,000 people from the city of Fort McMurray.

The monster El Nino, riding on top of about one degree of background warming, has triggered widespread bleaching of the corals around the world, including our cherished - but apparently expendable - Great Barrier Reef.

More than half the corals in the largely pristine northern end are now dying or dead the reef's Marine Park Authority chief Russell Reichelt told the Senate earlier this month.

On the plus side

However, a dose of of warming can be welcomed where it take off the chill - as in parts of the US - or in Sydney,   where summer feels like never lost of its grip even with winter just weeks away.

And all that extra CO2 is leading to a "greening" of the planet with about one-quarter of humans' carbon emissions being taken up by plants, a recent Nature paper found.

But many other changes are far from benign - at least according to the preservation of many existing eco-systems.

Less glamorous than corals, the kelp forests off eastern Tasmania are being destroyed by warm water species swept south by the strengthening and warming East Australian Current. Similarly, the massive dieback of mangrove forest in the Gulf of Carpentaria apparently linked to extreme weather got scant national media coverage.

And, as for the high Arctic and the remarkably prolonged above-average temperatures, changes up there are likely to be further from our daily consciousness.

Anomalously low #Arctic sea ice extent continues with the 48th consecutive day of a new daily record minimum value   pic.twitter.com/aVfFwAZx0J

??? Zack Labe (@ZLabe) May 16, 2016

But less sea ice means less light reflected back to space and more heat absorbed by the oceans - and so the cycle builds and so should our concern.

Spiral warning

In case you missed it, Ed Hawkins, a climate scientist at the UK's University of Reading, came up with the illustration below to help us appreciate the spiralling warming trend since the middle of the 19th century.

By that gauge, when the temperature increase breaks past the 1.5 degrees warming - perhaps in coming months before the El Nino in the Pacific fully stops giving back heat to the atmosphere - will be sufficiently concerned then to act?

Climate scientists, such as Professor Karoly, know globally warming limits agreed at international summits to prevent dangerous climate change - such as 1.5-2 degrees range agreed in Paris - are arbitrary in a similar way to 400 ppm.

"You'd be hard-pressed to find scientists agreeing that 1.5 degrees would be manageable for our reef," he said. "Look at what's happening to the reef this year - and that's with 1 degree warming."

Recent work by his team has identified that on current temperature and carbon emissions trends, the Great Barrier Reef will be hit by bleaching events every second year by 2035.

Other eco-systems, such as alpine ones, are also being affected as species helped by cool temperatures have literally nowhere to hide.

Big one to worry about

Natural fluctuations mean temperature spikes such as we have seen over the past year can recede - at least partly.

As this year's El Nino in the Pacific lurches towards becoming a La Nina - when equatorial winds turn back to be mostly west-ward blowing and strengthen - expect the run of record temperature reading to be broken.

With rising greenhouse gas concentrations, the heat we are trapping in the Earth's biosphere - the lands, air and seas - will keep on increasing.

And for those climate sceptics who thought the first decade of the 21st century marked a slowdown in temperature increases - the so-called "warming hiatus" - their case for holding off carbon emission cuts is about to get harder to make.

As Fairfax Media noted back in late 2014, a long-lived climate phenomenon named the Pacific Decadal Oscillation, has begun to switch to its positive phase. In fact, climate experts have in the past few days detected   it hitting a new high.

Such a PDO switch - it is an 11-year rolling average - would indicate oceans will become less of a sink for the planet's surplus heat - and may even give more of it back.

That means global conditions will favour more El Nino events but also when La Ninas come, they will tend to be more extreme.

For Australia that could mean more severe tropical cyclones, although parched inland regions may get some rainfall relief.

A PDO switch, however, would likely see an acceleration in global temperature increases, with all the unpleasant outcomes for corals, glacier melting and disappearing Arctic sea ice.

In other words, we could soon have a lot more to worry about.

A bowl of tiger penis soup sells for up to pound stg. 500 ($1315) across the nearby Chinese border.</p><p> A third of the Siberian tigers live in the area of the fire in the Sikhote-Alin Reserve, 720km north of Vladivostok.</p><p> Flames sparked by lightning two weeks ago have destroyed more than 3847ha of pine and are still raging out of control.</p><p>The blaze has spread quickly across the tigers' core breeding area because a lack of funds has meant that, for the first time in a decade, firebreaks were neglected this year. Unusually hot weather and a lack of winter snow have compounded foresters' problems and, this week, another of the four Siberian tiger reserves, Lazovksy, was also hit by fires.</p><p>Operation Amba, the Russian tiger conservation patrol, has been put on emergency alert and an appeal launched for money to clear firebreaks.</p><p> Andrei Yargin, a conservationist for Operation Amba, said few pigs and deer, on which the tigers prey, were left in the area around the burning forest so, in the past few days, there had been increasing reports of tigers around nearby villages.</p><p> He said if the patrol did not get there first, villagers usually shot the tiger. There were also worries the fires would only get worse.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P0W-XGP0-TXN5-T26G-00000-00Firefighters battle strong winds in effort to control spreading blaze2003-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 14Firefighters battle strong winds in effort to control spreading blazeDAN PROUDMAN

THE bushfire that has blazed across Mount Sugarloaf for four days broke containment lines last night and surged into another 300 hectares of bush.

Rural Fire Service brigades and State Forest fire crews have worked around the clock to burn back and build containment lines since the fire was lit below one of the mountain's popular lookouts on Saturday.

It has been a tiring start to what could turn into another long bushfire season.

Lake Macquarie fire control officer Steve Sowter said it was hoped the fire could be kept to about 500 hectares by using a clearing for powerlines as a fire break.

Strong wind last night pushed the fire through the power line and into remote bush.

It meant that instead of having the fire under control by today, firefighters will have to continue through the weekend.

"It has been a long haul for the first fire of the year, but our firefighters have risen to the occasion," Mr Sowter said.

"This is year three, we have had two bad seasons and although we have not had many bad fires in Lake Macquarie other than last November our firefighters have travelled to many other areas fighting fires."

He said employers had again helped his firefighters stay on the front line, some allowing their workers time off to fight the fires while other crews were turning up for an eight-hour shift after finishing their work.

"This has been a 24-hour operation since last Sunday and with the wind blowing from the west it has made it an extremely difficult task," he said.

"We are looking at another two days before containment, I would think."

No buildings have been destroyed.

A television building near transmission towers was saved after it caught alight.

More than 200 partygoers and other sightseers were evacuated from the area on Sunday after the fire sped along an escarpment.

TOUGH FIGHT: East Morisset firefighter Greg Chick hoses down embers behind the backburn at Mount Sugarloaf yesterday. - Picture by Peter Stoop

Similar conditions forced 10,000 people to evacuate late on Thursday.</p><p>"It's almost impossible to stop a fire that's moving like this one," a British Columbia Forest Service spokesman said.</p><p>Witnesses reported an entire suburb on fire in the city's southern outskirts late yesterday as flames leapt from building to building, some of which could be seen exploding from the intense heat.</p><p>Officials did not know how many homes were lost but no deaths or major injuries were reported.</p><p>The fire outside Kelowna, in the Okanagan Lake region about 300km east of Vancouver, began on August 16 with a lightning strike in the mountains that destroyed an estimated 17,000ha before moving towards the city.</p><p>British Columbia, suffering its worst fire season in decades, has been under a state of emergency since the beginning of August. urn:contentItem:7V3D-4T50-Y9B7-734G-00000-00UK: Princes William and Harry pay respects to bushfire victims2009-02-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSUK: Princes William and Harry pay respects to bushfire victimsBelinda TaskerLONDON Feb 24

  Princes William and Harry have expressed their shock and sadness at the devastation caused by the deadly Victorian bushfires.
   The second and third in line to the British throne made a brief visit to the Australian High Commission in central London on Tuesday to sign a condolence book for the hundreds of families affected by the blazes.


   They spent about five minutes discussing the fires with high commissioner John Dauth, consul-general Paul Ganly and acting agent-general for Victoria Ian Marland before signing the book and meeting a large crowd of the commission's female staff.
   "Prince William and Prince Harry were deeply shocked and saddened by the forest fire disasters that have struck Victoria recently," they said in a joint statement released by St James' Palace.
   "They just wanted to pay their respects to the Australian people today and let those who have been tragically bereaved and others who have been left homeless know that their thoughts and prayers are with them."
   Dauth gave the princes yellow ribbons to wear on their suits in commemoration of the more than 200 people killed by the fires, prompting Prince Harry to joke he would continue wearing his throughout the upcoming Ashes cricket series.
   The high commissioner told the princes how more than 100 people had signed the condolence book while many others had sent donations and letters of support.
   "They were interested to know what the current situation is and were alarmed, as are we all, by the further dangers of the fires in Victoria," Dauth told reporters.
   "Prince William said he assumed that (the donations and letters) were from expatriate Australians and he was surprised and I think pleased when I told him we had very many letters from British people.
   "I think they felt pleased they had been here and they felt part of the contribution the royal family has made to marking this sad time in Australia."
   Prince William also appeared to impress a group of about 15 swooning female members of the high commission's staff as he stopped for a quick chat before leaving.
   Ebonee Bailey-Gregory, from Hobart, was among those keen to catch a glimpse of the princes and said she found Prince William full of charm.
   "He asked if a lot of people had come through and if we were all Australians and if we knew people back home who were affected," she said.
   The visit by the princes to the high commission comes a week after their grandfather, the Duke of Edinburgh, signed the condolence book.
   The Queen has also made a private donation to the Red Cross appeal for bushfire victims, while Princess Anne attended last weekend's National Day of Mourning memorial service in Melbourne.

urn:contentItem:7V2V-F151-2R6N-636T-00000-00Emergency not over, residents told to get ready2009-02-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisAPg. 4Emergency not over, residents told to get readyPaul Austin

Victoria's bushfire emergency is not over, with today and Friday looming as extremely dangerous.

People in the Warburton Valley and Yarra Valley could come under direct threat today.

Fire chiefs are warning residents of these areas that if they plan to leave rather than stay and try to defend their properties, they should leave early today.

Country Fire Authority state duty officer Neil Bumpstead said residents would be most at risk after the wind change forecast for this afternoon.

He warned that if fire did reach the Warburton Valley, people who had left should be prepared to stay away for several days.

"We cannot stress enough that with limited road access in the Warburton Valley, traffic may become congested," he said.

"Being on the roads is dangerous during a fire threat."

The Enoch Point area, near Gaffneys Creek and south of Eildon, was of particular concern, with winds expected to turn north and north- westerly today at speeds of between 20km/h and 30km/h.

State duty officer at the Department of Sustainability and Environment Andrew Graystone said today's forecast was also for extreme forest fire danger in the Mallee and very high forest and grassland fire danger across the state, with the exception of East Gippsland.

The CFA has declared today a day of total fire ban in the north-western, north-eastern, eastern and central districts.

Premier John Brumby urged people in fire-prone parts of the state to implement their fire survival plans.

Mr Brumby said no Victorian should need to be reminded that the state was very dry after a drought lasting many years and then the baking heat of recent weeks.

"It doesn't need much to make them [fires] run," he said.

"So for people in those threatened areas, put your fire survival plan in place and if you're going to stay and defend, do all the things that are in the rule book."

Concerned about a rift between the CFA and the firefighters' union about how the fire services performed on Black Saturday, Mr Brumby called for an end to finger- pointing.

He said Victorians should work hard to avoid a repeat of what happened after the Ash Wednesday fires of 1983, when many firefighters resigned from the CFA "because lives were lost and they thought they hadn't done enough, that they'd failed".

"That's the last thing we want in Victoria now," Mr Brumby said on radio before yesterday's National Day of Mourning service.

"I don't know of any firefighter who didn't do their best."

Mr Brumby said the bushfires royal commission would investigate all issues, including the performance of the CFA and other emergency services and the adequacy of fuel- reduction burning policies and emergency warning systems.

with Clay Lucas

urn:contentItem:59V1-MRK1-JCMN-Y0GH-00000-00'The Big Bang Theory' 7 RECAP: Ep. 8: 'The Itchy Brain Simulation' : Sheldon is Diabolical; Lucy Meets Raj2013-11-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexis'The Big Bang Theory' 7 RECAP: Ep. 8: 'The Itchy Brain Simulation' : Sheldon is Diabolical; Lucy Meets RajAnshu Shrivastava

Nov 15, 2013 (International Business Times Australia:http://au.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex)
RECAP of "The Big Bang Theory" Season 7 Episode 8 "The Itchy Brain Simulation": Penny wants to know from Leonard if he ever played the dartboard. Leonards says that he did play and broke a window. The window is located far away from the dartboard, which is on the main door. Sheldon wants ski-ball tickets as he has finally decided on the price he wants for them.


Leonard gives Sheldon the ski-ball tickets from a box and also pulls out an ugly, itchy red sweater, which was knitted by her aunt. Sheldon finds that there are less tickets and wants to see if there are more in the box. Leonard blocks Sheldon's attempt to check the box. Soon, he tells Sheldon not to flip out because he did not return a DVD that was rented on Sheldon's name, seven years ago.
Sheldon is calm and acting reasonable, which freaks out both Penny and Leonard. Leonard tells him that being reasonable means not to fixate on the DVD, not waking him up in the middle of night or nagging him while he is on the toilet. Sheldon tells him that it is no picnic for him, too to talk to him while he is on the toilet.
Sheldon reminds Leonard that he should have remembered that the unresolved issues make him uncomfortable. It is like an itch in his brain that he cannot scratch. Sheldon has a solution and asks Leonard to put on the itchy sweater and share the experience with him. Leonard agrees to do that to prove that one can have a problem and solve it, without looking like a complete lunatic. He is expected to wear the sweater till he returns the DVD. However, he is unable to return the DVD because the owner of the DVD store is dead.
Leonard thinks that it is time to take off the sweater and he tells Sheldon that I didn't use it to antagonise everyone around me. However, Howard suggests that he seeks out the next of the kin, which Sheldon things is a pretty good idea. Leonard has to keep wearing the itchy sweater, which has put itchy rashes all across his upper body.
Also, the sweater has made Leonard an itchy mess. Howard describes him as a person who is impersonating a lunatic bear, showing that only he can prevent a forest fire. Sheldon is says that Leonard is a walking a mile in his metaphorical shoes. At Penny's apartment, Penny wants him to take off the sweater since Sheldon is not there to watch, but Leonard refuses to do that as he does not want Sheldon to win.
Leonard is unable to find anyone related to the dead DVD owner, and his patience has given-up. He almost screams when Sheldon suggests that he look for his relatives in countries such a Lebanon. Sheldon finally tells him not to flip out at the revelation that seven years ago, he found out the DVD is late and paid for it. Amy calls Sheldon's revelation diabolical, while he tells her that he kept the DVD thinking that this might be a teachable moment and it was a long wait for him.
At Cheesecake Factory, Amy and Bernadette spot Lucy and tell Penny that she is one who broke Raj's heart. Penny goes and asks Lucy when she broke-up with Raj via email and also tells her that Raj is a mess all thanks to her. Lucy says that she broke-up with Raj because she thought it was easy and wants another waitress. "I may be a bad waitress but you are a bad person," Penny tells Lucy.
Lucy sends a message to Raj to meet her at a coffee shop. Raj wants to know if they can meet again, but Lucy says that she is seeing someone else. Penny fixes Raj with a girl and Raj thinks it is not possible that the girl is ready to date him, and tells the girl that he can just be a side-dish. Girl screams at Penny for fixing her with Raj and Penny screams at Raj.

urn:contentItem:7V38-00D0-YBDY-R309-00000-00Fireys on red alert Victoria set for scorcher2009-02-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 18Fireys on red alert Victoria set for scorcherMegan McNaught

EXHAUSTED firefighters are preparing for another potential horror fire day on Friday.

The weather bureau is tipping another scorcher, with a top of 38C combined with northerly winds and a southwesterly change.

Fire fighters will spend the next couple of cooler days frantically creating dozer lines and backburning to try to contain the fires before the weather heats up.

Weather bureau senior forecaster Richard Carlyon said the next couple of days would be a holding pattern, weather wise, before the danger day on Friday.

``Things will be gradually heating up and we will be facing another critical fire day,'' Mr Carlyon said.

He said the wind change would happen about 6pm on Friday and could bring with it a couple of showers and lightning strikes.

Department of Sustainability and Environment spokesman Kevin Monk said firefighters yesterday were able to downgrade urgent situations at Upwey in the Dandenong Ranges and at Daylesford northwest of Melbourne, but warned residents to be alert.

At Upwey, a fire that started in the Birds Land Reserve on Monday had been contained, but the CFA had warned residents in adjacent areas to be on the lookout for flying embers in the tinder-dry conditions.

``A second spot fire started south of the main fire so we used dozer lines and helicopters on those fires,'' Mr Monk said.

``Even though the fire is not posing a threat, the communities of Upwey north of Glenfern Rd need to be aware that fire activity in the area has increased and has the potential to impact directly.''

Mr Monk said 400 firefighters were at Daylesford, 110km northwest of Melbourne, attempting to contain a forest fire spread over 2800 hectares.

``We've got dozers working on that, and that's where we may get some spots under the southerly conditions.

``The conditions are so dry that it only takes a small spark and the fire can race off.''

At Warburton, east of Melbourne, the threat eased after firefighters battled overnight to get on top of that blaze.

At Won Wron a fire had yesterday burnt 1300ha and was burning in an easterly direction, prompting urgings to residents to be on alert. Mr Monk said fire fighters would be on red alert on Friday.

``Those conditions are always a concern for us, and the possibility of new fires starting is a worry,'' Mr Monk said.

Premier John Brumby said that only rain could snuff out the fires. He said it was a miracle the blaze threatening Upwey was contained with minimal damage to property.

``(Friday) is nothing like February 7 in terms of temperature or wind, but nevertheless we're looking at something at the top end of the 30s and, in the north of the state, the low 40s,'' he said.

urn:contentItem:517R-FHR1-JD3N-53SJ-00000-00Why you don't need to fear a burn-off2010-10-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 46Why you don't need to fear a burn-offSCIENCE REPORTER CLARE PEDDIE

PERFECT spring days are just right for burning bushland under controlled conditions, the State Government says.

Residents can expect to see smoke and even flames in the Adelaide Hills over coming weeks, as the Government turns up the heat on prescribed burns in parks and reserves.

The team, with staff from the Department of Environment and Natural Resources, Forestry SA and SA Water, has a hectic schedule with more burns planned this season than last.

Up to 118 burns, covering more than 19,100ha, are planned in spring this year and autumn next year. This compares with 92 burns, covering almost 11,000ha, conducted last bushfire season. And the burning has begun, with the first taking place in the north-east corner of Belair National Park on Monday this week.

The next is due on Tuesday or Wednesday, depending on the weather conditions, says Mike Wouters, the department's acting manager of fire management. ``We need 20 or 25 degrees, some wind but not too much,'' he said.

``We don't want it too dry, but not a wet cloudy day. The humidity needs to be below 40 per cent. The perfect spring day is a good day for burning.

``If it's too hot, the fuel dries out too much and the fire will be too intense and potentially uncontrollable. Same as if there is too much wind, the fire spreads too much and we have less control.''

The Government's main aim is to reduce bushfire risk across South Australia. A major focus is the Mt Lofty Ranges, where 41 prescribed burns are planned, covering 1200ha.

Mt Lofty Ranges Fire Cooperative convenor Richard de Groot said burns were targeted to reduce heavy fuel loads in strategic areas of parks and reserves. ``There is conclusive evidence both nationally and internationally that prescribed burning lessens the impact bushfires would otherwise have on assets and the community,'' he said.

``Reducing heavy fuel loads is very important, because it can make it easier to control a bushfire, help prevent a bushfire spreading to residential areas, and ultimately save people's lives and property.''

But no amount of prescribed burning can protect the community from the worst bushfires.

Forest fire expert Dr Kevin Tolhurst, from the University of Melbourne, gave advice to Victoria's Royal Commission into the Black Saturday fires which claimed 173 lives.

He said the vegetation that becomes fuel for a fire is just one source of energy. The other sources of energy are the weather (wind and heat), the topography, and the fire itself (radiation, convection, mass-ignition effects).

``In some circumstances, a wildfire, even in a recently prescribed burnt area, may cause catastrophic damage even if the extent and degree of damage is diminished,'' he said.

``Prescribed burning to reduce fuel hazards must be considered in combination with other impact mitigation strategies such as fire suppression, building design and planning, communication, and avoidance.''

CSIRO research scientist Justin Leonard said the fuel close to homes and in the last 50m right up to the back fence was ``absolutely critical'' but in some cases fires were unstoppable.

``Once the weather escalates past certain thresholds, that fire in the landscape won't stop at a break or a prescribed burn or anything,'' he said.

``Prior to that escalation, there are many opportunities to be more active at suppressing an initial start, halting the fire front or reducing the extent of the fire while conditions are mild.''

That is the question posed in Survivor: The Australian Outback, a sequel to last year's reality-adventure series Survivor.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The second series strands 16 new castaways in the Australian outback as part of an elimination game in which the last person standing wins almost $2 million.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Over 42 days the castaways have to outwit, outplay and outlast each other by competing in various challenges for rewards.</p><p>And every few days they have to visit the tribal council to cast their votes and expel one of their own until the final winner emerges.</p><p> They have to build their own shelter and find food while multiple camera crews capture all the fly-on-the-wall action.</p><p> The backdrop for Survivor: The Australian Outback  is the Herbert River in North Queensland, just south of Cairns.</p><p> The area is characterised by sharp contrasts in weather and terrain, including tropical rainforests, treacherous rapids and spectacular waterfalls. The survivors risk potentially deadly encounters with crocodiles, snakes, spiders and poisonous plants.</p><p> The 16 new survivors are: Personal trainer Alicia Calaway, 32; administrative assistant Amber Brkich, 22, custom auto designer Colby Donaldson, 26; corrections officer Debb Eaton, 45; footwear designer Elisabeth Filarski, 23; aspiring actress Jerri Manthey, 30; Internet project manager Jeff Varner, 34; chef Keith Famie, 40; US Army intelligence officer Kel Gleason, 32; bartender Kimmi Kappenberg, 28; retired police officer Maralyn Hershey, 51; software publisher Michael Skupin, 38; singer/songwriter Mitchell Olsen, 23; Harvard law student Nick Brown, 23; teacher and farmer Rodger Bingham, 53; and nurse Tina Wesson, 40.</p><p> In this week's episode, self-appointed leader Michael has been annoying his tribe with a relentless pursuit of wild pigs, but will he bring home the bacon? And a forest fire puts the Ogakor tribe under threat.</p><p>  *  Survivor: The Australian Outback screens on Channel 9 on Wednesday at 8.30pm.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P6W-5080-TXN5-R2WS-00000-00Pay TV2005-04-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisTHE GUIDEPg. 20Pay TVSaturday April 16ROBIN OLIVER

Dogs with Jobs

National Geographic, 6pm

Guard dogs, sniffer dogs, sheep dogs and guide dogs are all familiar, but what other jobs can dogs perform? In the North Island of New Zealand, Steam, a five-year-old huntaway, herds more than 1000 deer to fresh pastures each day. Eighteen-month-old Heavenly Angel, a Pyrenean mountain dog, would probably enjoy a job like Steam's and so her handler, Marshall, takes her to try out guarding goats for a northern Californian farmer, while Mike, an eight-year-old Dutch shepherd and a veteran of a US secret service pilot project established in the late 1990s, has an extraordinary nose for counterfeit money.

Ultimate Response

A1 (digital), 9.30pm

A sudden forest fire is sweeping out of control through Banff National Park in Canada and specialist search-and-rescue helicopter teams must pluck confused hikers off smoke-covered mountains. Across the country, on the West Coast Trail in the Pacific Rim National Park, emergency calls are coming in from hikers when the 77-kilometre trail become so muddy that's its injury rate matches a downhill ski facility.

Dame Alicia Markova

Ovation, 5.30pm

Famed for her interpretations of the lead roles in Giselle, Swan Lake and The Nutcracker, English ballerina Alicia Markova began her career when she was spotted by Russian dance impresario Serge Diaghilev. That was in 1920 when she was 10 years old. Under Diaghilev's watchful eye, Markova become a star and exerted a major influence on the emerging British ballet scene and with her dancing partner, Anton Dolin, founded the London Festival Ballet, which in turn became the English National Ballet. She was still dancing Giselle at the age of 48 and performed on stage for the last time in the early 1960s. Subsequently, she worked as a dance director and teacher. Dame Alicia died in December at the age of 94.

Good Eats

Lifestyle Food (digital), 9.30pm

The thought of preparing souffle has bugged cooks for ages, but is host Alton Brown really going to help when he insists a strong measure of science is all that's needed to control the egg foam? Then there's the question of managing heat in the oven. Brown goes for a cheese souffle.

urn:contentItem:4M0C-GW30-TX53-B2B3-00000-00Residents urged to prepare for increased risk over summer2006-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Residents urged to prepare for increased risk over summer'Mega fires' threatMEX COOPER

SUMMER is set to be hot, dry and dangerous with the threat of ''mega fires'' already sparking fear in bushfire experts.

Victoria's Emergency Services Commissioner Bruce Esplin yesterday warned residents to be ready to face fire as the Bureau of Meteorology predicted less rain and higher temperatures than average until the end of the year.

Mr Esplin said spring bushfires in the Otways and New South Wales had taken some people by surprise but that there was no such thing as an average fire season anymore.

''We see fire seasons starting earlier, lasting longer and the number of extreme fire days increasing,'' he said.

Mr Esplin said the term ''mega fire'' was being used by American firefighters to describe huge fires that were almost impossible to control no matter what resources were used.

He said fighting mega fires required preparation including fuel reduction burning and community awareness.

''Escapes from fuel reductions can't be 100 per cent avoided . . . but they are critical tools in bush fire prevention,'' Mr Esplin said.

The Department of Sustainability and Environment has announced fuel reduction burns will be done in Lorne and Aireys Inlet by the end of the year.

But Athol Hodgson, a former chief fire officer and president of Forest Fire Victoria, said more burn-offs were needed to prevent a devastating summer.

''Fuels have been building up and we've had a dry winter which is a precursor for a very severe fire season provided it doesn't rain like hell from now until the end of February,'' Mr Hodgson said.

The bureau yesterday predicted a 75 to 85 per cent chance of higher than normal maximum temperatures between October and December; and a 60 to 75 per cent chance of less rain than usual.

''I think we are going to see some very big fires this summer in our native forests,'' Mr Hodgson said. ''The highest risk areas are far East Gippsland, Wombat Forest and that part of the Grampians not yet burnt, and possibly the Otways.''

Surf Coast Shire's fire prevention officer Jill Diebel said the council would send out fire notices to residents in at-risk coastal towns in November, a month earlier than normal. It will also inspect homes for fire hazards.

urn:contentItem:4V8P-D0R0-TXN5-V1NR-00000-00Mouse traps2009-01-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisMETROFilmPg. 7Mouse trapsDonna Walker-Mitchell

MORALS IN THE TALE NEED NOT HAVE A STING, WRITES DONNA WALKER-MITCHELL.

AS A youngster, Dustin Hoffman loved the Disney animated movie classic Bambi. Decades later, the two-time best actor Oscar winner sat down with his children to watch the film about a young deer dealing with the sudden death of its mother.

Hoffman saw it with new eyes.

"Bambi is frightening," he says, raising his eyebrows. "When all those animals get burned in the forest fire - you don't realise until you have kids how frightening that is.

"The same with Pinocchio. I remember reading Pinocchio to my kids and he falls asleep by the fire and his legs get burned. It's extraordinary, some of these stories. They are brilliant but powerfully brutal."

Hoffman is front and centre in the new wave of Hollywood animated films, lending his voice to two movies last year. The 71-year-old voiced martial arts guru Master Shifu in the animated blockbuster Kung Fu Panda, the third-highest-grossing film worldwide in 2008 with $US631 million ($924 million) in takings.

Next, Hoffman brings Roscuro the rat to life in The Tale Of Despereaux, a visually beautiful computer-animated film with a look inspired by Flemish artists.

Based on the Newbery Medal-winning book by Kate DiCamillo and set in the kingdom of Dor, where royalty, peasants and rodents once lived in harmony, the story examines the themes of betrayal, revenge and forgiveness.

The kingdom is shaken up when the inquisitive Roscuro wanders into the queen's castle and accidentally falls into her soup. The monarch has a fatal heart attack when she sees Roscuro and, as a consequence, the grief-stricken king banishes all rats to the dungeon.

The hero of the film is big-eared misfit mouse Despereaux (voiced by Matthew Broderick), whose love of reading books rather than chewing them puts him at odds with other rodents.

Joining Hoffman and Broderick in the all-star cast are Sigourney Weaver, Kevin Kline, Tracey Ullman and William H. Macy.

Weaver, who narrates the film, says she can relate to the theme of forgiveness. As a teenager toiling away in drama school, teachers and peers laughed at her desire to make a living out of acting.

More than 50 movies and three Oscar nominations later, the New Yorker has proved them wrong but says she doesn't hold a grudge. "Forgiveness is a powerful thing and I love the fact it's being dealt with in a movie for children. I was just so touched by the story."

THE TALE OF DESPEREAUX

Directors Sam Fell, Robert Stevenhagen Voices by Matthew Broderick, Dustin Hoffman, Sigourney Weaver.

Out Thursday.

urn:contentItem:50X0-8D61-F0JP-W0CX-00000-00Star-gazers pin hopes on magnificent seven2010-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisTHE TUESDAY REPORTPg. 17Star-gazers pin hopes on magnificent seven

SCIENTISTS say they have identified a sun-like star with as many as seven different planets -- including one that might be the smallest ever found outside the solar system.

If confirmed, the planetary system around HD 10180, a star more than 100 light years distant, would be the richest ever discovered.

One astronomer says it is part of a growing body of evidence that the universe is full of planets -- and that a bunch of them could be similar to our own.

``The really nice thing about finding systems like this is that it shows that there are many more out there,'' said Alan Boss, of the Washington-based Carnegie Institution for Science, who wasn't involved with the find.

``Mother Nature really had fun making planets.''

Though most of the planets identified are large -- about 13 to 25 times the mass of our home -- those behind the discovery, announced at a recent international conference in France, say they are nearly certain they have identified one only 1.4 times the size of Earth.

That would be the smallest planet ever spotted outside of those which orbit our own sun.

Scientists have been spotting planets beyond our solar system for the past 15-odd years, and they have now catalogued about 450. But most finds have been limited to one or two or three planets, usually gargantuan balls of gas similar to Jupiter or Saturn.

But at up to seven planets, the new discovery is almost as rich as our own solar system, which counts eight.

Christophe Lovis, of Geneva University, one of the scientists behind the find, said the first five were most comparable to Neptune.

``They are made essentially of rocks and ice. They have a solid core. But on top of that is a layer of gas, of hydrogen and helium most likely,'' he said. ``They are probably not habitable.''

The sixth is possibly a Saturn-like planet, while the seventh, the smallest, would be so close to its star that its ``year'' would take just over a day.

Lovis and his team haven't been able to observe the planets directly, which is typical. Few planets can be seen against the blazing light given off by their much more massive parent stars.

The European Southern Observatory compares the challenge to ``spotting a dim candle in front of a raging forest fire''.

So the scientists used the observatory's 3.6 metre telescope at La Silla, Chile, to study the star itself. Over six years, they took 190 measurements, checking it for the telltale wobbling caused by the gravitational forces of nearby planets.

Boss noted that the method was ``biased toward finding the big guys'' because the greater the planet, the greater its gravity and the more it made its parent star wobble. But he said the discovery showed that finding smaller planets was still possible.

``This field has gone from zero to close to 500 planets in just 15 years,'' Boss said.

``Fifteen years we did not know about the big guys. Earth-like planets are going to be quite commonplace.''

The find was made by researchers from Switzerland, France, Germany and Portugal and has been submitted to the journal Astronomy and Astrophysics.

urn:contentItem:44KC-YMJ0-0197-93WX-00000-00<published>2000-11-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:50:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>ARTS & ENTERTAINMENT; Pg. 110</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Myth in modern context</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Kate Herbert</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Theft of Sita</p><p nitf:lede="true">By: Nigel Jamieson</p><p nitf:lede="true">Where and when: Malthouse; final show today</p><p nitf:lede="true">Bookings: 9685 5111</p><p nitf:lede="true">Reviewer: Kate Herbert</p><p nitf:lede="true"> THIS telling of the abduction of Sita is distinctively Australian-Indonesian.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> It is told evocatively with Indonesian shadow puppets and contemporary Indonesian images of environmental destruction and rebellion, mostly in English and with plenty of Aussie slang.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The narrative is a funny and moving portrayal of the Sanskrit epic, The Ramayana.</p><p>Director Nigel Jamieson collaborated with composer Paul Grabowsky, director of puppetry Peter Wilson and dalang (Indonesian chief puppeteer) I Made Sidia to create a rich visual and aural world.</p><p> The production's great strength is the successful parallel it draws between the myth of the abduction of King Rama's wife Sita by the demon Rawanna and modern issues of ecology, power, wealth and urbanisation.</p><p> Sita is stolen as she wanders the forest and is kept caged in a sprawling city by Rawanna. Her kidnapping comes to represent the rape of the landscape of Indonesia.</p><p> Jamieson uses the clown servants of King Rama as the protagonists. On their quest to rescue Sita they face forest fire, famine, wood-chipping, white-water rafting and a surreal urban chaos.</p><p> The shadow puppets are innovative. Not only do we see traditional characters but forest animals, instrumental creatures playing rock songs, and huge electric pylons and buildings.</p><p> In addition, there is distressing imagery of real riots and blasted landscapes in Indonesia.</p><p> The musicians, puppeteers, actors and singers are secreted for most of the 95 minutes at the rear of the stage. They create magical and disturbing images designed by Julian Crouch and lit by Damien Cooper.</p><p> The spectacular musical composition by Grabowsky combines the sounds of Indonesian gamelan music with melodic or cacophonous contemporary Western music. The effect is transporting.</p><p> Sita is challenging both theatrically and sociologically -- and a hoot for the family. Kids loved it.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P0N-JXR0-TXN5-S26B-00000-00Out-of-control bush burn-off threatens homes2003-04-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Out-of-control bush burn-off threatens homesAndra Jackson with AAP

The CFA was monitoring a forest fire last night after a planned burn-off went wrong and became a 1000-hectare blaze, earlier coming as close as 200 metres to homes.

The fire in the Cobaw state forest between Kyneton and Kilmore, 60 kilometres north of Melbourne, was started on Friday night. The Department of Sustainability and Environment had planned to burn 600 hectares, CFA spokesman Ian Major said, but a hot northerly yesterday blew it out of control.

By yesterday afternoon the fire had consumed an extra 400 hectares and had spread to private land, Mr Major said.

The CFA took control of fighting the fire once it reached private land, sending in 300 CFA and Department of Sustainability and Environment firefighters, 75 tankers and seven planes. A northerly wind pushed the fire south. It jumped the Kyneton-Lancefield Road near Twin Bridges, at one stage forcing its closure.

The strong northerly carried smoke as far as Melbourne.

Residents in scattered housing close to Croziers Road off the Kyneton-Lancefield Road were told to watch out for flying embers and to put their fire protection plans into operation.

Last night the fire was still burning in the forest and casting embers 200 to 250 metres ahead. It had been brought within containment lines but was still not under control, Mr Major said.

CFA units were to stay on the job in case the wind picked up.

Department of Sustainability and Environment chief fire officer Gary Morgan said "no one is to blame" and residents who had suffered losses might be able to claim compensation.

The fire has angered residents. Chris Litchfield, who manages the Cobaw Country House bed and breakfast, said it was too early to be burning off. "It's foolish, to say the least," she said. "People are angry about it. The Cobaw forest has never been so dry in white history."

Alan Cooper, of the Cobaw Ridge Winery, complained about a "lack of communication" with residents. -- with AAP

Photo: CFA officers battle a blaze near a farmhouse in the Cobaw forest near Macedon. PICTURE: JASON SOUTH

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Vic: Firefighters still battling close to 50 blazes in Victoria</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Darrin Barnett</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>MELBOURNE, Jan 10</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Victorian firefighters are still battling to control nearly 50 fires in Gippsland and the state's north-west, most of them in steep and inaccessible country.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Mullungdung State Park forest fire, Victoria's largest, has burnt through more than 6700 hectares, while another north of Cann River has exceeded 110 hectares.</p><p nitf:lede="true">A fire in Holey Plains State Park has burnt more than 500 hectares, with residents of nearby Stradbroke encouraged yesterday afternoon to beware of flying embers ahead of changing wind patterns.</p><p>It was anticipated the Holey Plains fire would be contained, though not controlled, sometime overnight.</p><p>More than 1200 personnel from the Department of Sustainability and Environment (DSE), Department of Primary Industries (DPI) and Parks Victoria (PV) have been fighting the fires, with about 700 set to begin their shift early today.</p><p>Victoria's 24 specialised firefighting aircraft, 20 bulldozers and a large fleet of specialised 4WD vehicles were deployed yesterday, with the Ericksson aircrane working on two fires southwest of Sale.</p><p>Fire management teams have been established at Yarram, Sale, Erica and Heyfield in Gippsland, and at Mansfield, Myrtleford, Tallangatta and Corryong in north-east Victoria.</p><p>Meanwhile, a number of roads, walking and vehicle tracks in the vicinity of the fires in the north-east have been closed.</p><p>All walking tracks on the Mt Feathertop area of the Alpine National Park including the Razorback, Bungalow Spur, the Bon Accord Spur and Diamantina Spur have been closed pending further notice.</p><p>Also shut down are the West Kiewa Logging Road in the Alpine National Park, all walking and vehicle tracks in the Mt Arthur and Grey Hills area, and the Mt McLeod and Sandy Creeks tracks within the Mt Buffalo National Park.</p><p>Intending visitors to parks and forests in eastern and north eastern Victoria have been asked to call the Parks Victoria Information Centre on 131 963 and listen to local radio stations.</p><p>Temperatures are expected to heat up gradually over the coming days and efforts are being focussed on containing as many fires as possible before the weekend.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4TVJ-XX60-TXX1-F09R-00000-00health matters2008-11-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisBODY AND SOULPg. 16health mattersNicola Conville

My own prescription for health is less paperwork and more running barefoot through the grass." Leslie Grimutter, poet

READ THIS:

Flight Of The Hummingbird by Michael Yahgulanaas (Hachette Livre, $22.99)

This little book contains a simple parable with a strong environmental message. It tells the tale of a hummingbird who tries to put out a forest fire by carrying drops of water in her beak, highlighting the power of taking small steps to achieve a big goal, and reminding us that we all need to help to create the world we want for ourselves and our children.

Beauty pack Summer's nearly here and my thoughts are turning to holidays. But don't rely on hotel shampoos and conditioners - they're often little better than washing-up liquid.

Try the new all-organic travel pack from Endota instead. It contains everything you need for a long-haul flight or a weekend away:

Native Mint shampoo and conditioner, River Salt and Desert Lime shower gel and Lilly Pilly body moisturiser. Available from Endota spas nationally for $35. Visit www.endota.com.au

Everything in order

Anyone can get die suddenly, and if our affairs are not in order, it means loved ones are often left to make tough decisions. Affairs In Order is a do-it-yourself pack which helps you organise your financial, health and personal affairs. From $89 per pack, visit www.affairsinorder.com.au or call (02) 9660 1045.

Furry friends

Protect your pet from ticks and fleas the natural way with a Ticlace - a sturdy Baltic amber necklace which can be worn by dogs and cats of all sizes. As the amber rubs against the animal's fur, it creates a mild static electrical charge, completely undetectable to the animal, which gives the tick a shock. It also releases a resinous scent, which deters ticks and fleas from staying in the animal's coat. The Ticlace is effective within two to three weeks and lasts for up to 12 months of continuous use. From $39, visit www.ticlace.com for more information.

Six ways to boost your fitness

1 Write your exercise plans in your diary and stick to them like you would any other appointment.

2 Mix up your routine to maintain your interest and stop your body from reaching a plateau.

3 Turn off the TV one night and dedicate that time to a game of tennis with friends.

4 Make one lunchbreak an active hour - go for a brisk walk in the park before eating.

5 Take any opportunity for incidental exercise - see every set of stairs as a chance to tone your thighs and butt.

6 Whenever you can, clench your muscles in your core - your butt, stomach or your pelvic floor.

urn:contentItem:5C8V-KJD1-JD3N-5322-00000-00Paradise loses none of its charm2014-05-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 34Paradise loses none of its charmKIMBERLEY VLASIC

A COMPANY that started on the smell of an oily rag is now recognised as a leader in eco-tourism, thriving on a crusade to protect and conserve the Great Barrier Reef.

As Passions of Paradise prepares to mark its 25th anniversary, owner and managing director Alan Wallish has reflected on the initiatives that have the Cairns operator hailed a "Reef hero".

"It's a philosophy," he said. "It's a culture that emanates from me and others that have always been involved in the boat.

"I grew up in Canada, although I was born in Australia, so I always saw the Great Barrier Reef as something really special, particularly in winter when the snow was 3m high.

"When I came to Cairns I had a real international outlook on its value to everybody.

"The whole environmental focus has been a key component of running our business from day one, and it just strengthens every year." For more than a decade, Passions has partnered with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority for the Eye on the Reef program, training staff to conduct regular scientific monitoring.

These surveys feed into a data management and reporting system, which provides marine park managers and researchers with information on Reef health status and trends, species distribution and early warnings of environmental impacts.

The company sails home each day to reduce fuel consumption and was the first dive operator in Cairns to be recognised by the Professional Association of Diving Instructors (PADI) for its ocean conservation work.

Last year, Passions' reputation as a leader in eco-tourism was further cemented when it received the prestigious Ecotourism Australia Innovation in Ecotourism Award and was granted Climate Action Leader status. It was one of only 13 companies across the country.

Among the myriad environmental programs it implements are the PADI National Geographic Dive Program, which gives passengers the chance to observe and explore like an underwater scientist, and Mr Wallish's brainchild, Save A Shark.

"I introduced Save a Shark about five years ago," he said.

"It came about because I saw a similar program being run in Thailand called Save the Elephant and I wanted to do the same sort of thing on the Great Barrier Reef.

"At the time, shark finning was a really big issue and movies were coming out like Sharkwater, highlighting the fact that 80 to 90 per cent of our sharks were under threat." The program has educated more than 100,000 passengers on issues facing sharks and will have raised $30,000 by the end of this year for student research through the Oceania Chondrichthyan Society.

Mr Wallish is director of the Association of Marine Park Tourism Operators (AMPTO) and Passions staff are helping to stop the spread of crown of thorns starfish by killing about five of the coral-eating animals each month as part of an AMPTO-led eradication program.

The company also recently introduced a carbon offset scheme which raised $900 last year towards planting trees in the Daintree.

"To my knowledge we're one of the only boats in the whole of Australia that as a tourist operator offers passengers the chance to offset the carbon footprint of their trip, very similar to the way the airlines do," Passions' environmental sustainability co-ordinator Russell Hosp said.

But it hasn't always been smooth sailing for Passions, which was dreamt up by Mr Wallish and his friend Steven Carter in 1987.

"We quit our jobs, cashed in our superannuation, sold our cars and basically started to build a boat," he said.

"We raised $25,000 and ran out of that in about a month.

"So we talked our parents into mortgaging their houses, raised another $120,000 and brought in a couple of other people and two years later ended up building the first boat." Passions 2 was born a decade later.

Mr Wallish invested in Passions 3, an 82ft fibreglass catamaran, in 2003. It was delayed for two years after a forest fire destroyed the first model. The company now employs 29 staff and takes 25,000 passengers to Michaelmas Cay National Park and its exclusive mooring at Passions Reef each year.

It aspires to be the benchmark Reef operator for eco-tourism in Australia and sales and marketing manager Adam O'Malley said interactivity and engagement was key to achieving this goal.

"We could quite easily put a video up, show passengers the colours of fish and coral," he said.

"But to take that one step further and talk about the threats to the Reef and what we're doing to protect it, then giving people the chance to get involved is really something quite special and we're really excited about where we're going to go with that." Passions of Paradise celebrates its 25th anniversary on May 30.Do you know someone doing something to preserve the Great Barrier Reef? To nominate them as a Reef Hero, email editorial@tcp.newsltd.com.au

urn:contentItem:5G57-BRP1-F0J6-J146-00000-00Burning desire to fight fires2015-06-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisMAGAZINE_Pg. 21Burning desire to fight fires

There are many dedicated men and women working with the state's emergency service organisations. As part of a short series, COREY MARTIN speaks with Launceston firey, Robert Featherstone, still going strong after 40 years' service.

GOUGH Whitlam was Australia's prime minister, Cyclone Tracey destroyed Darwin and Countdown first aired on television when Robert Featherstone became a firefighter.

The year was 1974 and a 16-year-old Mr Featherstone was on his year-11 summer break when he signed up with the Tasmanian Rural Fires Board.

"I went back to school and finished Rosny College in '74 on the Friday and started work on the Monday as a casual," he recalled.

"They used me as a casual until they were able to get approval for a position in the state headquarters purchasing area.

"A lot of the work at that time involved checking the fire trails, doing fuel reduction burns and supporting the volunteers."

In 1979, the Tasmania Fire Service was formed and Mr Featherstone was working in the Huon region, an area he called home for 15 years.

In 1989 he moved to the Northern region as the Tamar district officer, before moving on to the Launceston Fire Brigade in 1994 and remains today.

In February 2009, he managed a team in Victoria to help combat the devastating Black Saturday bushfires, a disaster that killed 173 people.

Mr Featherstone is Launceston's senior station officer, Perth volunteer officer and has spent 41 years in the service carrying out an interest that began at an early age.

"When I was three years old I got a little fire truck pedal car for Christmas and the first time I used it I took it down to the end of the footpath, put the ladder up against the post and it slipped on the star picket, which almost impaled me ... so I've never trusted ladders since," he said.

"I got interest in burning off at about 10 because the grandparents had a shack down on the peninsula and she was a good cook, I'd be in the kitchen trying to get the cake mix.

"To fix that she gave me a roll of newspaper and box of matches and told me to get rid of the bracken on the bank, I've been burning off ever since."

Mr Featherstone said a majority of the work firefighters do revolves around the acronym PPRR - plan, prepare, respond and review.

He said that system worked by planning for all four seasons, preparing the gear, responding to fires and reviewing how things went.

Mr Featherstone said he had made a few mistakes that colleagues fail to let him forget; like the time he sent a crew to investigate a spot-fire in the distance, which turned out to be the red moon rising.

"One of the best pieces of advice I received was way back from one of the bosses who said 'Robert, whenever you go to a forest fire the first thing you do is get a campfire going, put the billy on, sit down and have a cuppa tea'," he said.

"It gives you a chance to see which way the clouds are blowing, how long it's going to take to get the crews here and come up with a decent plan - instead of going in and busting your boiler and losing the fight.

"Education for the elderly and young to see if they're ready for what may happen is also important ... you see a few deaths along the way in car accidents, house fires and just stupid acts.

"I attended the Brisbane Street backpackers fire where 20 people were stuck on the first floor and one person died.

"It's not nice seeing some of the things that have happened, so all the campaigns and education that we provide have made things better over time."

He said technology use had been fundamental in the service becoming more efficient.

Mr Featherstone said tools such as smartphones, tablets, thermal-image cameras and vehicle identification were priceless.

"If we get the vehicle rego before we get to the job, we can type it into the laptop and can tell what sort of car it is, where to cut it, where the airbags are, where the battery is and where the disconnect points are - all that before we get there," he said.

"The same can be applied to information about properties and things like Google maps is extremely beneficial, plus there are four radios on the trucks and I'm carrying the work phone, personal phone and a pager.

"When I first started I spent a lot of time sharpening axes ... we are lucky to use an axe now.

"I have picked up some of the knowledge and experience from people who had had 50 years service when I started ... and I try and hand that on to the people coming through now - it's knowledge that was gained 80 years ago and is still valid."

He said he had most enjoyed the camaraderie of his colleagues, which he described as a second family.

He said being in a team of 15 other firefighters provided plenty of laughs, trust, experiences and rewarding accomplishments.

Tasmania Police were invited to take part in this series, however, were unable to supply The Sunday Examiner with a candidate.

Launceston senior station officer Robert Featherstone has spent 40 years with the Tasmania Fire Service Picture: NEIL RICHARDSON

urn:contentItem:4580-CNW0-0197-53CV-00000-00<published>2000-05-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:50:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 9</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Nuke town cleared in face of inferno</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>ROBERT LUSETICH  * Los Angeles correspondent</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">CARS overpacked with belongings jammed the road out of Los Alamos, New Mexico, throughout the night as one of the worst bushfires in years threatened to engulf the home of America's nuclear weapons laboratory.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> All of the town's 11,000 residents were ordered to evacuate yesterday, as what began as a routine deliberately lit fire to burn off undergrowth in a nearby forest turned into a nightmarish inferno that 800 firefighters are virtually powerless to stop.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "We won't put anybody in harm's way," said fire department spokesman Jim Paxon, defending the decision not to put firefighters in front of the fire, but to attack it from the sides and back instead.</p><p>New Mexico Governor Gary Johnson said there was little left to be done, but to hope that gusting winds, which were fuelling the fire, would abate.</p><p> President Bill Clinton declared Los Alamos, which started losing homes on its western edge by mid-morning and had lost about 200 by nightfall, a disaster area, and authorised the Federal Emergency Management Agency essentially to take over the town and use whatever means necessary to handle the situation.</p><p> Los Alamos was the site where the first atomic bomb was made in 1945. There have not been nuclear weapons at the site since the mid-80s.</p><p> Nuclear and non-nuclear explosives are stored in steel and concrete bunkers buried beneath the ground.</p><p> "Of all the things that could threaten the nuclear material, a forest fire is very low on the list," said Chris Judson, a spokesman for the laboratory.</p><p> Residents are angry that the national park service went ahead with the burn-off even though it had weather forecasts showing the potential for disaster was high, primarily because of increasing winds.</p><p> Forecasters said yesterday's gusting winds of up to 55kmh were set to intensify today to about 80kmh, creating a fresh horror scenario for firefighters.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata
