urn:contentItem:4PHB-MVD0-TXN5-R1XY-00000-00Greece begs for help to fight killer forest fires2007-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisNEWSInternational NewsPg. 45Greece begs for help to fight killer forest firesGeorge Hatzidakis

GREECE'S worst forest fires in decades have killed 44 people and it was feared the toll could rise with villages still cut off by flames sweeping through parts of the Peloponnese peninsula.

Greece has called for urgent help from its European Union partners.

Soaring temperatures and high winds hampered rescue efforts.

In some areas firefighting and rescue aircraft were grounded by high winds.

"As of this moment, we have 87 active fire fronts," fire department spokesman Ioannis Stamoulis said yesterday.

Two French tourists were among the dead.

A number of villages have been cut off by a wall of flames, stretching 80 kilometres from the Ionian Sea on the west coast of the Peloponnese to Mani on the peninsula's southern tip.

Politicians interrupted election campaign schedules and Prime Minister Costas Karamanlis went to the area, saying: "These are very difficult times for all of us."

His conservative Government has been widely criticised for its slow reaction in dealing with a spate of forest fires during the summer and its popularity has fallen. "The primary task now is to put out the fires and repair the damage," Mr Karamanlis told reporters after meeting fire officials near the front.

Authorities yesterday started sifting through destroyed homes in the search for survivors while 500 soldiers were sent to help.

"It's a tragedy," a witness told Greek television. "I can see the burnt bodies of a mother holding her child in her arms. Further away there are more bodies. It's terrible."

At least 19 firefighting aircraft and 18 helicopters have been called in, and the Government has ordered a state of emergency in the provinces of Lakonia and Messinia.

A combination of soaring temperatures, hot winds, drought and arson has caused the upsurge in forest fires after tens of thousands of hectares were scorched in an even more intense heatwave last month.

A total of 170 fires broke out on Thursday and Friday, while at least 124 fires were raging across Greece yesterday, authorities said.

Summer heat and high winds helped rekindle fires across other parts of southern Europe.

In Italy, where blazes are spreading across many southern areas, an 83-year-old man died near the southern city of Potenza yesterday.

Police said he was probably trying to put out a fire.

Italy's Civil Protection Authority said Thursday had been the worst day for forest fires in Italian history.

TWO PHOTOS: DEVASTATION: A villager surveys the damage in Artemida after a forest fire swept through the Peloponnese peninsula yesterday.Picture: Reuters; AFRAID: A woman watches a fire near her house on Evia Island, north of Athens. Picture: AP

urn:contentItem:4D9G-GHV0-015G-T2KV-00000-00<published>2004-09-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:50:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 25</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Korea blast riddle</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SEOUL -- A huge explosion has rocked North Korea, but US and South Korean officials said it was unlikely to have been a nuclear weapons test despite reports of a mushroom cloud.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The blast in northeast Ryanggang province, near the Chinese border, appeared much bigger than a train explosion that killed at least 170 people in April.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The New York Times reported the Bush Administration had received recent intelligence reports that some experts believed could indicate North Korea was preparing its first nuclear weapons test explosion.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Reuters</p></bodyText></section><p>But US officials said there was no definitive explanation yet, though Thursday's blast did not appear to be nuclear.</p><p> ""People are pretty sure it's not a mushroom cloud and not a test of any kind," a State Department official said.</p><p>South Korea's Yonhap news agency said a mushroom cloud up to 4km in diameter was seen after the blast in an area near missile bases, and that the blast was seen from satellites. But South Korean Unification Minister Chung Dong-young said the explosion was unlikely to have been part of the communist North's nuclear arms ambitions.</p><p>Japan said it was checking the reports, North Korea has said nothing so far, and there was no immediate reaction from China.</p><p> An official at a hospital in the Chinese city of Ji'an, on the Yalu River across from North Korea, said they had not heard of any explosion or received any injured.</p><p> Aid agencies in Pyongyang said they had not heard of an explosion.</p><p> Thursday was the 56th anniversary of North Korea's founding, and the reclusive communist state often stages extravaganzas and big events to mark important anniversaries.</p><p>South Korea, Japan, China, Russia and the United States are seeking to persuade North Korea to return to the negotiating table to discuss its nuclear weapons ambitions.</p><p> The North, which threatened at earlier talks to test an atomic bomb, has said it doubts more negotiations will help.</p><p> China was the last country to set off an above-ground nuclear test, in 1980. It carried out its last nuclear test in 1996.</p><p>Yonhap quoted one source as saying it could be a forest fire. Other possibilities include a failed missile engine test, a high-explosives test as a precursor to a nuclear blast or an industrial accident.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4D63-4Y30-0045-5413-00000-00<published>2004-08-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:50:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>A;</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Blaze got away on Jan 17: expert</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Megan Doherty</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The McIntyre's Hut fire in NSW broke away from its western containment line - jumping west across the Goodradigbee River - as early as noon on January 17 last year and again some time before 9.30 that night, an ACT coronial inquiry heard yesterday.CSIRO fire behaviour expert Phil Cheney told the inquiry into the January 2003 bushfires that the main part of the McIntyre's Hut fire progressed eastwards towards Canberra, hitting Duffy about 3.15pm on January 18, while the breakawayto the west headed south and east before crossingNamatjira Drive behind Mount Arawang about 4pm, then travelling at a ferocious pace. Mr Cheney's final report about the spread of the bushfires in the ACT and NSW between January 8 and 18 last year was examined at the inquiry yesterday.By contrast, a combined submission to last year's NSW coronial inquiry into the Brindabella Range fires by the National Parks and Wildlife Service and NSW Rural Fire Service said only "on 18 January under the influence of extreme fire weather, the McIntyre's Hut fire broke to the west across the Goodradigbee River in at least two locations [late morning]". Mr Cheney said yesterday he made further investigations of reports that breakaways had occured across the Goodradigbee River, which was being used as the western containment line for the McIntyre's Hut fire on January 17.He told the inquiry that some time around midday on January 17 the western edge of the McIntyre's Hut fire broke away across the Goodradigbee River, where crews were patrolling by foot.</p><p>That breakaway was contained but another breakaway across the river occured in the vicinity of McIntyre's Hut some time before 9.30pm.Mr Cheney said the breakawayon the western side burned towards the south behind the main fire on January 18.It then burned eastwards between the earlier breakawayfrom the eastern perimeterof the McIntyre's Hut fire and the northern flank of the Bendora fire in the ACT.The rapidly moving "centre"fire crossed Namatjira Drive behind Mount Arawang about 4pm."There may have been some variation in there but it appeared to be pretty consistentand maintaining a rate of spread of 20km per hour, which is the fastest documented rate of spread of a forest fire anywhere to my knowledge," Mr Cheney said.The inquiry has been adjourned until September 7.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CANBER-2293580</dc:identifier><dc:source urn:contentItem:4P7G-YMG0-TXN5-R2NJ-00000-00WORLD NEWS1989-08-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 15WORLD NEWS

CREATOR OF SOOTY DIES

HARRY Corbett, creator of glove puppet bear Sooty, has died. Corbett died on Wednesday "peacefully in his sleep", but his family did not release the news until yesterday, a Thames Television spokesman said.

Son Matthew Corbett, who took over the character in 1973, is on holiday, apparently unaware of his father's death.

TOURISTS FLEE

TOURISTS fleeing a forest fire on the Greek island of Thasos were being evacuated yesterday as a huge wall of flames threatened to engulf several villages.

The fire, which began mid-week, has ravaged 3,000 hectares of pine forest and farm crops and burnt down a camp site, houses and a sawmill.

AMMO TRAGEDY

A TRUCK hauling 800,000 rounds of military aircraft ammunition caught fire early yesterday in Arizona, leaving a woman dead and a man critically injured, US officials said.

The two were believed to be husband and wife.

Five hours after the fire began the truck's load of 20 millimetre aircraft cannon ammunition was still exploding sporadically.

SEX DISGRACE

A TOP US Navy commander in Britain has resigned in disgrace after sex complaints by five women under his command.

Highly decorated Vietnam veteran Captain Carl Gustafson was ordered before an Admiral's Mast hearing - the US equivalent of a court-martial.

He did not contest allegations of "non-consentual touching", conduct not becoming of an officer, fraternisation and oppressive conduct.

urn:contentItem:458P-R6F0-0197-818F-00000-00<published>1996-12-10T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:50:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FULLPAGE, FEATURES; Pg. 32</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Clint's all fired up</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">*CLINT EASTWOOD is expected to star in Men And Fire, based on Norman Maclean's reconstruction of a true-life lethal forest fire.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Maclean, who wrote the book A River Runs Through It, tells the story of a team parachuted in to fight a fire in the American West in the early 1950s.</p><p>*CUBA Gooding Jr. has no trouble with nudity, on screen or off.</p><p>Asked if he was embarrassed by having to strip down in the film Jerry Maguire, Gooding responded by dropping his pants.</p><p> "We all came into this world naked, so what's the big deal?" Gooding asked.</p><p> In the film, Tom Cruise has the title role of a sports agent representing a professional football star played by Gooding, who lifted weights to prepare for the role and tried to perform his own stunts.</p><p> Although he did a perfect somersault off a trampoline in rehearsals for one stunt, studio executives still had doubts, so they asked him to do it again the next day. The second time wasn't so perfect.</p><p> "It's a good thing I was wearing my helmet, because I landed smack on my head. I really felt numb," Gooding said.</p><p>"The nurse on the set thought I had a pinched nerve. I got up and said: "OK, I'm done. No more stunt work."</p><p> Gooding, who got his start in Boyz N the Hood, has film credits including A Few Good Men and Outbreak.</p><p>*COUNTRY singer Wynonna said she was "shocked and saddened"</p><p>by the sexual harassment and discrimination suit filed against her last week by a female farmhand she sacked.</p><p> Wynonna said she planned to counter-sue the ex-employee, Andria Surles, who has made the allegations.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4582-1GG0-0197-F36N-00000-00<published>1996-11-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:50:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BUSHFIRES THREATEN HOMES</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>MIDDAP C / GREBER J</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">KEYWORD-HIT</p><p nitf:lede="true">Bushfires threaten homes</p><p nitf:lede="true">By CHRISTINE MIDDAP and JACOB GREBER A SPATE of bush</p><p nitf:lede="true">fires threatened dozens of homes on the Gold and Sunshine coasts yes</p><p nitf:lede="true">terday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Fire crews on the Sun</p><p nitf:lede="true">shine Coast saved 15 homes from a blaze which raged through forest</p><p nitf:lede="true">near Landsborough.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>About 50 rural, auxiliary and Department of Primary Industries</p><p>firefighters were called to Mt Mellum when fire approached houses.</p><p>Earlier five spot bushfires broke out in the Gold Coast hinterland.</p><p>Five Mt Nathan Rd homes were evacuated when flames leapt a road and</p><p>came within metres of houses. The blaze began in the Nerang</p><p>State Forest.</p><p>Several houses were also in jeopardy last night as a massive fire</p><p>at Esk, 80km north-west of Brisbane, destroyed more than 500ha of</p><p>private land and state forest.</p><p>Fire officers fighting the Esk fire were forced to scale down</p><p>operations as night fell and conditions became dangerous.</p><p>According to firefighters, the area is inaccessible country, hilly</p><p>and rough and considered dangerous because of collapsing trees.</p><p>They feared for eight or 10 houses about 4km west of the 3km fire</p><p>front, although they are apparently unoccupied.</p><p>Earlier in the day the Esk Shire Council sent water trucks and a</p><p>bulldozer to cover a 2km-long back-burn to prevent the fire from</p><p>spreading.</p><p>The cause of the blaze was not known.</p><p>Other bushfires broke out at Mt Tamborine, Helens</p><p>vale, Southport and Clagiraba.</p><p>Queensland Fire Service Sunshine Coast district rural</p><p>inspector Glen Mills said the Landsborough fire began when some</p><p>one began burning leaves.</p><p>Southport station officer Bruce Smith said the Gold Coast fire</p><p>brigade and the rural brigade were expecting a hot and busy summer.</p><p>""It's not even summer yet and we've been flat out."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4T2J-4T80-TX5N-00NP-00000-00Grammy nominee makes return after long illness New album Childs play2008-07-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisENTERTAINMENTPg. 37Grammy nominee makes return after long illness New album Childs play

TWO decades after her debut album went double platinum in Australia and she was nominated for three Grammy Awards, Toni Childs is back with a new album.

Best known for her hit songs Don't Walk Away and I've Got To Know Now, Childs has spent the past eight years recovering from Graves Disease, which she was diagnosed with in 1997.

Keeping The Faith is her emotionally hard-hitting and inspiring return to singing and songwriting.

``The best part of re-emerging from the darkness and learning to embrace music once again, is simply the opportunity to evolve and get down to the core of my purpose,'' said Childs.

``Looking back, it's a really wonderful journey. I feel like I'm a phoenix rising, burned down to an ash and then coming through that forest fire healthier and stronger than ever before.''

Childs releases her album in Australia next month and will tour the county in September and October. Keep The Faith will then be released in Europe and the US in January next year.

The positive end to her medical exile has given Childs a new lease on life, which is evident in her new songs.

``I'm grateful because everything feels like a second chance for me,'' she said.

``I see the ability to write, record and perform as a wonderful privilege.''

Keep The Faith has a much more basic and rootsy sound compared with her albums from the 1980s.

``Every song is written on guitar, instead of being driven by drum loops and sequencers like it was when I made my first two records,'' she said.

The title track was written for a close friend who was going through a custody battle.

``His trials made me think of how I cope when my world seems to be coming apart,'' said Childs.

``I know I can see the light . . . but sometimes even the people who love you most don't know what you need to go through to fly again.

``What started as a song for someone I care about became a really important song for myself.''

She hoped the album and her story would inspire others through the depths of illness.

``I realised that I had a lot of resistance to loving myself, and I wasn't alone,'' she said.

``I started truly loving myself and over a period of time, the disease started turning itself around.

``This process was gradual over two years, but the end result is that I have not had to take meds since 2001.''

The album also features Revolution, a vintage recording with her band from 1997, which serves as a time

capsule for the year her world suddenly changed. Keep The Faith will be released in Australia on August 16.

urn:contentItem:4P8B-R7X0-TXN5-S134-00000-00CFA fire-spread prediction methods risk lives: report2000-01-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4CFA fire-spread prediction methods risk lives: reportTHE STATERICHARD BAKER

Victorian firefighters are putting their lives at risk by using inaccurate prediction methods to calculate the spread of forest fires, according to the CSIRO.

For the past six years, the CSIRO has been conducting Project Vesta, a multi-million-dollar study of the behavior of fire in dry eucalypt forest.

After lighting nearly 100 experimental fires around Australia, preliminary results from the project show prediction methods in use now can underestimate the rate of spread by as much as three times.

Researchers found that many regional and rural fire brigades were still using the prediction systems developed in the 1960s by bushfire expert, Mr Alan McArthur.

The leader of Project Vesta, Mr Phil Cheney, yesterday said the McArthur forest fire spread-table still worked for bushfires in their infancy, but it became increasingly inaccurate as fires grew. The study has also revealed that wind gusts under a forest canopy do not travel more than 40 metres and that average wind speeds in a close area of forest can differ by up to 20 per cent, making fire-spread predictions even more difficult.

Researchers found that a threshold wind speed of between 12 and 15 kmh made a huge difference in the behavior of forest fires.

The Country Fire Authority's research and development manager, Mr David Nichols, said the CFA had received a brochure from the CSIRO outlining the problems with the present prediction system and that within the next week, all brigades throughout the state would have received the brochure.

"The issues that they've raised we find very important and we support what they've done thus far," Mr Nichols said.

Mr Cheney said it would be at least two years before the full implications of the study were known.

urn:contentItem:58W0-50V1-JD34-V1C0-00000-00MAKING A SUITABLE KIDS' MOVIE CHOICE ISN'T CHILD'S PLAY.2013-07-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisSHORTLISTPg. 2MAKING A SUITABLE KIDS' MOVIE CHOICE ISN'T CHILD'S PLAY.cal wilson

One of the biggest risks in life is taking a four-year-old to the movies. There are so many things to consider. How long is it? How many people will he annoy? Is he going to want to eat his own body weight in popcorn? Will it be too scary? Too grown-up? Too mind-numbingly boring for mummy and daddy? So, thinking "What could be more harmless than classic Disney?" we took him to Peter Pan.

When you watch a favourite kids' movie as an adult, it's always full of little things you missed the first time around. For example, Tinker Bell deliberately flashing her knickers, or all those topless mermaids. Sure, there was strategic hair placement, but there was also some serious aquatic side-boob.

Like Mickey Rourke, Peter Pan hasn't aged that gracefully. I'd never picked up that P. Pan was actually a bit of a dick, pitting Wendy against the mermaids, against charming racist stereotype Tiger Lily.

With adult eyes, there's a lot that's a little off about the movie. At the beginning of the film, Mr Darling displays some serious anger-management issues, and then he and his wife leave their children in the care of a St Bernard wearing a hat. In the '50s, dog-based child care may have been fine, but these days it would get you a visit from a child protection officer.

Of course, my son didn't care about any of that. He just wanted to see the pirates, but even they gave me conniptions, with Captain Hook casually murdering another pirate just for singing. As someone who is easily annoyed by off-key warbling, I could sympathise, but if my son picks up that attitude, my husband is in grave danger.

I had rosy memories of that other classic Bambi, with it's wobbly-legged fawn and adorable bunny chum Thumper. Revisiting it a few years ago, I was shocked by the horror: Bambi's mother gets killed by hunters, Bambi gets shot, and there's a fatal forest fire. Then there's the most gruesome part of all: Thumper succumbs to a bout of myxomatosis and becomes a zombie, then Bambi gets infected, and they eat all the hunters.

I thought maybe we'd have more luck with a modern children's film. Now, there are some kids' movies (Toy Story, Up) you can happily go to without a child in tow. Dinosaur Train: Dinosaur Big City is not one of them. How is that even a proper title, for a start? It's like terrible fridge poetry.

For those of you who aren't staff members to an under-five, Dinosaur Train is basically about Buddy, a young tyrannosaurus, who's been taken in by pteranodons (flying reptile things), without any acknowledgement that, at some point in later life, he's going to treat his adopted family as hors d'oeuvres.

To get round that whole the-interesting-dinosaurs-didn't-all-live-in-the-same-era conundrum, there's a time travelling train that picks them all up, so they can hang out together. I hope I haven't made that sound too interesting, because DT:DBC is cheesy and tedious, and made me want to jam my hand in a door. By the end of it, I was longing for some Peter Pan-style inappropriateness, or Bambi's hunters to take out some of these flying reptiles.

We finally hit the jackpot with Monsters University, which is the prequel to Monsters, Inc. It turns out that explaining the idea of a prequel to a little kid is quite tricky. In the end I went with: "They finished telling the story in the first movie, but then they wanted to make some more money."

My son just couldn't get the concept that this was a story about Mike Wazowski (one-eyed pea creature) and Sully (Mardi Gras yeti) when they were younger, so explained it to himself as "They're just pretending to be other people", and we left it at that.

The animation is beautiful (and incredible), the voice work is fantastic and there are the requisite good gags for grown-ups. Initially, I worried the monsters' scariness might actually be too scary, but Digby lapped it all up, and loved every minute. So, after that success, we've decided to relax. Next week we're taking him to see World War Z.

You can follow Cal on Twitter: @calbo

urn:contentItem:4632-G9C0-015G-Y2WM-00000-00<published>2002-06-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:50:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 13</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest officer blamed for inferno</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Darrell Giles</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A US Forest Service employee has been charged with starting the Colorado fire that has damaged 40,000ha and threatened the homes of 45,000 residents.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Forestry technician Terry Barton, 38, admitted starting a campfire and that it got out of control. Then she tried to cover up her involvement.</p><p>Barton was patrolling the forest, warning campers about the dangers of accidentally setting off a massive forest fire. There was a fire ban in part of the forest.</p><p>She said she started burning personal papers within a designated campfire ring, where fires normally would be allowed, and then tried to put out the blaze.</p><p>Bill Leone, of the US Attorney's Office, said Barton told investigators she reported a fire but not that she had started it.</p><p>This led the Forest Service to question what she was saying.</p><p>"She attempted to suppress the fire but it grew," Mr Leone said.</p><p>Barton was charged with setting fire to timber in the national forest, damaging federal property in excess of $US100,000 ($180,000) and making false statements. If convicted, she faces up to 10 years in prison and $US250,000 in fines.</p><p>Barton was scheduled to make an initial court appearance in a Denver federal court today.</p><p>"I want to begin by saying, this is one of the hardest announcements I've had to make in my career," said Rick Cables, regional forester for the Rocky Mountain Region.</p><p>"I'm shocked and with a lot of other people, in a state of disbelief. I'm saddened to say that one of our employees has admitted to starting the Hayman fire."</p><p>Twenty-two homes were destroyed in the blaze.</p><p>Firefighters gained ground yesterday on the wildfire that had burned within 75km of Denver city limits since it start on June 8.</p><p>With the blaze about 35 per cent contained, about 5400 people remained out of their homes.</p><p>It was one of seven fires burning in the state and another blaze flared in southwest Colorado and forced the evacuation of more than 330 homes.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5VYG-N2V1-JBJ7-N3W2-00000-00From the Archives, 1986: Chernobyl nuclear accident2019-04-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisFrom the Archives, 1986: Chernobyl nuclear accidentDavid Porter

On April 26, 1986, a catastrophic nuclear accident occurred at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in SovietUkraine. We revisit the tragedy with this 1994 article from the archives.

First published in The Age on January 29, 1994

Into the danger zone

DAVID PORTER has just returned from a journey deep into the exclusion zone around the Chernobyl nuclear reactor. He found an eerie wasteland of deserted farms and ghost towns. But people still work there.

IT IS snowing in the Ukraine and the road to Chernobyl, 130 kilometres north of the capital, Kiev, is pristine white.

Fields and tall forests of pine and oak slide past on either side as we slow to pass a horse and haycart, driven by two peasants clad in thick, black coats to keep out the cold.

It could be a rural scene from a century ago, or even just 10 years ago, when this region was the bread basket of the former Soviet Union.

But life has changed dramatically here ever since reactor number four at the Chernobyl nuclear power station exploded in the first hours of 26 April 1986, showering caesium 137 and other radioactive fallout over central Europe, Scandinavia and Britain.

Now, no one dares eat the fruit on the trees or the fish in the streams around Chernobyl and the countryside has become a wasteland, a land of ghost towns and deserted farms.

Officially it is called the "Exclusion Zone" _ a no-go area extending in a 30-kilometre circle around the Chernobyl nuclear power station, near the border with Byelorussia.

But to everyone in the Ukraine, it's known simply as "the zone". It is a place of warped humor and knowing smiles, where alcohol is banned but vodka appears from under the table the moment guests or visitors arrive.

With the vodka come the wry jokes about radiation. Take a full bottle of vodka and follow each shot with a red wine chaser. When the vodka bottle is empty you won't need to worry about radiation.

The Russians call the zone "the land of alienation". The Ukrainians call the people who have worked in it "the liquidators". In both countries, the word "sarcophagus" now refers to only one thing _ the zone's epicentre, the concrete and metal coffin of Chernobyl's reactor number four.

The scientists say no one will ever live in the zone again, though criminals and outlaws are said to roam its "forbidden forests".

About 800 former residents have also moved back to their villages inside the zone, defying repeated attempts by guards to drive them away.

They are mostly older people without children who say, "we are going to die soon anyway, we want to die in our own homes".

TO ENTER the zone requires official permission, which usually takes a week of tangling with the Soviet-inspired bureaucracy.

We have the help of Valentina Pastushyna, who is the chairwoman of the Kiev branch of the Ukraine Republican Society of the Children of Chernobyl, the public organisation which has helped arrange eight visits to Australia by children affected by the Chernobyl disaster.

She has managed to organise our permit in just three hours. She tells us to bring our passports; we might also need some US dollars.

We are joined on our journey into the zone by the imposing figure of Giorgy Batula, who heads the Chernobyl Committee, a public organisation set up to unite all who were evacuated and suffered, including the liquidators.

Giorgy and Valentina are both former residents of Pripyat, a city of high-rise apartments housing 58,000 people, three kilometres from the reactor. It was evacuated in the days after the explosion. This is a rare chance for them to return.

Giorgy was the deputy chief of construction in Pripyat, an important person in what was a growing city. Valentina is meeting her husband Sergei, who works in Chernobyl village designing automated machinery that will replace jobs now done manually at the reactor plant. Like most of the 6000 people employed in the zone, he works two weeks on, two weeks off. During his shift, he lives 40 kilometres away in a dormitory suburb and commutes daily by bus. No one is allowed to live full-time in the zone.

We arrive at the 30-kilometre gate, where the zone begins, and are told we must transfer to an approved vehicle. As a precuation against contamination, there are two types. One is allowed to travel inside the 30-kilometre zone but not into the 10-kilometre inner zone around the reactor. The other can travel inside both zones, but can never leave the 30-kilometre perimeter.

Giorgy has shown the guards our authorisation to enter and we are soon driving off in a battered green van towards Chernobyl village, 18 kilometres from the reactor.

Chernobyl was once a pretty village of farm cottages and fruit trees.

Now it is overgrown and abandoned, except for a few hundred people who travel here daily to work in administration. It lies at the end of a narrow road lined with forests, flanked by signs warning against throwing cigarette butts and matches out the window. The trees hold so much radiation, mainly in their bark, that authorities fear any forest fire would send clouds of radiation into the atmosphere In the village's central square stands a large statue of Lenin. I try to ask Valentina why it hasn't been pulled down. This has been a common fate of communist heroes elsewhere in the former Soviet Union.

But she doesn't understand. I make out as if to kick the statue. This she does understand and immediately nods and bursts into laughter. It is not clear how much of a catalyst the Chernobyldisaster was for the Ukraine's push for independence, but it certainly played a part.

We visit three different buildings for clearance and then pick up Valentina's husband, Sergei, and Nikolai Anysimov, an interpreter who has worked at Chernobyl for the past two years.

Nikolai worked at the petroleum institute in Kiev with American and British oil experts until the money ran out in 1990.

"With the coming of perestroika, the institute's research functions broke down. So I had to find some work and finally I came here," Nikolai says, as we drive off towards the reactor.

"These were agricultural lands before the accident. Now it is only wild grass. There are no activities here."

Down the road he points to a collection of mounds a few hundred metres away.

"A village called Kopache existed here before the accident. It was so badly contaminated that it was decided to break up all the houses and bury them into the ground. A few buildings survived. Now it's only grass and shrubbery. After they finished, they buried the bulldozers that buried the village.

"The same happened with the forests. The main radiation attack was like a narrow tongue. One part of the forest still lives. Right next to it, trees died within days. They turned yellow and red and their pine needles fell off. These trees have been felled and buried in the ground."

We pass nuclear reactors five and six which were under construction at the time of the explosion. Everything has been left as it was _ cranes hang motionless over the unfinished reactor towers. Trucks, buses, helicopters and building materials lie abandoned by the road. No one dares touch them.

Steam rises over water ducts coming from the two nuclear reactors that still operate. A third is under repair after a fire.

Nikolai points to a lake, which is the main water supply, and cracks a joke. "It's very abundant in fish. Very large fish," he laughs.

"But very much contaminated. By the way, we have found no cases of fish with two heads."

Reactor four was entombed in walls of concrete and metal five metres thick after the accident. Hence its name, the sarcophagus. But there are cracks and fissures in the casing. Nikolai says scientists have told him gaps were left deliberately so that air could get inside.

We stop in car park 300 metres from the sarcophagus. It has a sinister presence, borne out by Nikolai's firm instructions not to go near the fence where radiation is 10 times higher.

"We will not stay here long, maybe three minutes for some photos.

Because, you know, this is not a good place to be."

I am anxious that we leave even sooner. Nikolai says scientists still do not have a clear understanding of what caused the explosion and some believe there could still be fuel burning inside.

"There was a desire to produce more power, so there were overloads to the equipment. Then, they began to carry out some experiments, which were periodically performed at the plant. There were personnel who did not have the proper attitude. There were many other possible causes."

Before we leave, Nikolai points to a sign on a wall opposite the sarcophagus, put there by the Russians who built the plant. It reads: "We shall come to the victory of communism."

"Some scientists here are very pessimistic about the sarcophagus," Nikolai says. "They say no one knows what will happen to it in the next half an hour, let alone the next 100 years. Everyone says the whole structure is shabby and not too stable and it will only stand for 10 years."

A plan to encase the sarcophagus in a larger dome of glass and ceramic has been developed by the French. This should last for 100 years.

"If men go inside the sarcophagus in protective suits it is only for a very short time," Nikolai says. "Mostly the data comes from the several hundred sensors installed inside.

Men who removed fuel and other debris from the reactor after the accident were allowed to work inside for only 30 seconds. For that, they earned a week's wages and a holiday in Kiev.

The main danger now is from background radiation and from contaminated land and groundwater. Nikolai says the radioactive debris fell in patches and some areas outside the zone are more contaminated than areas inside.

"We have just gone over a hot patch in the road," laughs Nikolai, as we drive away. "But it's OK. We were going fast."

The gathering darkness accentuates the eeriness of entering Pripyat, just three kilometres from the reactor. It is surely the largest ghost city on earth.

Before the accident, Pripyat housed 58,000 people in its high-rise apartments. Now it is empty, its residents were evacuated in the days after the explosion.

Think of the high-rise units in Collingwood; scatter dozens of derelict cars, trucks and buses around; take away all the people; and multiply it all 10 times. Then you have Pripyat.

Valentina and Giorgy point out their former homes. They are both very emotional at this point and Giorgy wipes tears from his eyes.

During our previous few days in Kiev, Valentina had taken us to visit several homes of families who were residents of Pripyat and victims of the Chernobyl accident. With Mrs Zina Botte, the Ukraine Consul for Melbourne, acting as interpreter, we were told many tragic stories, such as that of Klava and Leonid Pilypeyko and their children Sergei and Svetlana, who now live in the Kiev suburb of Vyshgorod.

Klava was bedridden for a year. Her arms, legs and face were swollen.

So were her thyroid glands, which were eventually removed in an operation in 1990. Now she takes thyroxine tablets daily. "I thought I was going to die," she says.

Leonid, too, has enlarged thyroid glands and the doctors have told him his heart is weakened. Their son, Sergei, also has enlarged thyroid glands and suffers respiratory problems. He goes to school one week on, one week off. Their daughter, Svetlana, suffers similarly.

Svetlana was one of the Chernobyl children recently stranded in Australia who were flown home for free by Lauda Air.

Klava said Pripyat before the accident was a paradise, a place full of colorful roses and children playing on swings. She believes the Chernobylexplosion and aftermath was foretold in the apocalyptic writings in the Revelation of St John, the last book of the New Testament. "There will be a heaven, but you won't be able to eat any of the fruit," she said.

Luba Sirosh was born 10 kilometres from Chernobyl and lived her entire life there until two days after the accident. She remembers her parents' farmhouse, where she grew up with eight brothers and sisters, as a "house full of laughter".

Luba said the explosion buried her eldest brother. Now her younger brother is also sick. She does not know how to help him.

Luba's father is also buried near Chernobyl village. She grieves that she cannot return to pluck the grass from his grave and lay flowers there. Like most former residents of Chernobyl and Pripyat, she knows she will never go back.

Officially, 42 people have died as a result of the Chernobyl disaster.

But the real figure could be hundreds or even thousands.

Giorgy peers through the gloom at Pripyat's empty apartments. He says a total of 130,000 people were evacuated from the towns, villages and farms around Chernobyl. "There are 68,000 people now registered as sick due to Chernobyl. They have different illnesses; the most common is swollen thyroid glands. There are already many cancers."

Nikolai says scientists believe that most radiation-induced cancers will not show up for eight to 10 years after the accident, which is a year or two from now.

Valentina expects that the victims of Chernobyl will die prematurely.

"Every slight illness sends fear through them ... that they are dying. Many children know they are sick, but don't really understand why."

She says all survivors have regular medical check-ups. This is partly so that doctors can monitor the effects of radiation. But while the hospitals treating the sick are clean and warm, much of the medical equipment doesn't work and there is a chronic shortage of medicines.

Even having simple vitamin supplements would help.

IT SEEMS incomprehensible that people already affected by radiation would voluntarily chose go back to work inside the zone.

Leonid Pilypeyko, who works at Chernobyl, just shrugged when I asked this question in Vyshgorod the day before. "There is very high unemployment in the Ukraine," he replied, "and there is a stigma against employing Chernobyl victims. It's a job and we get extra money and benefits, such as free public transport."

Giorgy Batula, too, returned to work inside the zone for six years as a supply manager and in the militia. A year ago he left to take up his job with the Chernobyl Committee in Kiev. "Sure, I'm happy," he says, when I ask him if he's glad to have left the zone.

Before we leave Pripyat, we are surprised to see lights on in one tall building. It's the former Pripyat Hotel. Nikolai can't resist another joke. "It's the hotel with the largest number of vacancies in Europe," he laughs.

There is a decontamination team working there. Nearby, scientists have built a greenhouse to study the effects of radiation on plants. The entire zone has become a giant laboratory for scientists.

"There are now many wild animals inside the zone _ wild boar, deer, foxes, wolves, rabbits, dogs _ much more than previously because there is no activity here, no industries," says Nikolai. "Swedish scientists come with rifles and go around the forest shooting deer and wild boar. They take samples from their flesh, meat and intestines to determine radiation levels and compare it to animals in Sweden."

Nikolai is not worried about the radiation in the zone. "At first I was. But now I've got accustomed to it, like most people here."

He says the authorities are very strict about who enters the zone and what is taken out. It's part of the image promoted by the nuclear industry about Chernobyl _ that the accident was a disaster, but that the danger was contained.

Security was tightened last October, when officials announced that a small quantity of nuclear fuel was stolen from Chernobyl.

As we leave Pripyat in total darkness and arrive at the gate denoting the 10-kilometre inner zone around the reactor plant, the guard in his cubbyhouse on the gate is sound alseep.

urn:contentItem:55BV-3R01-JD34-V220-00000-00Warning too late for off-the-scale fire danger2009-05-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Warning too late for off-the-scale fire dangerPatrick Durkin and AAP

The Country Fire Authority's fire danger index registered off the scale on the morning of Black Saturday but the public was not warned about this, CFA chief Russell Rees has told the opening of the Victorian Bushfires Royal Commission.

A fire behaviour expert also predicted via a map that one of the blazes would engulf Kinglake and surrounding towns hours before the first warning was issued.

But asked yesterday if he was made aware of this prediction, Mr Rees replied: "No, I'm now aware that there was a map produced but I was not aware on the day".

The commission heard yesterday that the McArthur Forest Fire Danger Index, designed to go up to 100, registered 328 on February 7.

Counsel assisting the royal commission, Jack Rush, QC, asked why the community had not been specifically warned it had gone off the scale.

Mr Rees said: "To understand those figures . . . you need to understand what they mean, so there needs to be an educative process. The language of low, moderate, extreme, high extreme is considered best to explain that scenario."

Mr Rees admitted one of the CFA's "core responsibilities" was to warn communities and it had done so "to the best of our abilities".

Mr Rush said an infra-red aerial scan took a snapshot of the Kilmore East fire at 12.33pm on February 7, which was relayed to the Integrated Emergency Coordination Centre in Melbourne. From the image, a fire behaviouralist mapped the path the fire would likely take between 2pm and 9pm, taking into account the south-west wind change.

Kinglake, Kinglake West, Strathewen, Pheasant Creek and St Andrews were all in the potential impact zone.

But, the commission heard, it was 5.55pm before an urgent threat message was issued for Kinglake and just 35 minutes later the town was under attack.

Of the 173 people killed by the savage fires, 159 died in the Kinglake region. Kinglake itself lost 38 residents and Strathewen lost 27.

When asked if an alert message could have been issued for Kinglake earlier, Mr Rees said: "There was smoke in the sky, there was a whole lot of things happening, there was a whole lot of activity around, in terms of fire in the district, and our message is very clear, that we get and give as much information as we have available".

Asked why he did not issue a radio warning about the danger until 7.45pm on Black Saturday, he said it had not been his responsibility.

Mr Rees said it was up to local incident control centres to decide what messages were given out.

No one in Victoria had a legal responsibility to warn the community about fire dangers, he said.

Under intense questioning, he said the community had "a responsibility as well to obtain information and make judgements".

The royal commission, chaired by Justice Bernard Teague, continues today.

urn:contentItem:45KY-P8F0-015H-925W-00000-00<published>2002-04-17T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:50:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forestry puts out spot fire over ashes</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>JANE LOVIBOND</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE embattled manager of Tasmania's forests has hosed down a potentially ugly row over the fallout from regeneration burns.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Forestry Tasmania's already bleak week threatened to deteriorate even further when outraged Judbury residents cried foul over a thick layer of ash that descended on their homes on Monday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Anxious to win a few friends, the corporation went into conciliation mode offering to right the wrongs with a "clean team" to wash down ash-laden roofs and replace contaminated tank water.</p><p>Gordon and Sharon McCallum were spoiling for a fight over Monday's late afternoon regeneration fire which they likened to an atomic mushroom cloud.</p><p> "It was a beautiful day and then at 3.30 it started," Ms McCallum said.</p><p> "Up it went just like an atomic bomb. Then the ash started to fall and my daughter thought it was a volcano.</p><p> "We'd never seen anything like it. There was no warning at all."</p><p> She said her washing was covered in fine grey ash and her curtains and bed linen wreaked of smoke from the fire she estimated to be 5km away.</p><p> However, her major concern was the roof of the family home, the only collection point for the household water.</p><p> "We all rely on tanks up here and have to be careful that our water does not become contaminated," Ms McCallum said.</p><p> "We can't filter it. Forest fire ash is very fine and washes straight into the tank with the next shower of rain."</p><p> Unable to control her anger she contacted the Geeveston district ForestryTasmania office and blasted the local authorities. The offer to clean the roof was immediate. After further negotiation the corporation yesterday offered to replace the McCallums' tank water.</p><p> The same offer stood for their neighbours who were similarly affected.</p><p> Ms McCallum intends spreading the word about Forestry Tasmania's conciliatory move to the other 14 households in her immediate neighbourhood of Sheoak Rd.</p><p> And given the almost truce-like conditions, she plans to tackle the corporation on a couple of other fronts -- water quality in nearby Judd Creek and a more economic and environmentally friendly disposal plan for wood stockpiled for regeneration burns.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5D7M-09X1-F0JP-W3PB-00000-00Using movie magic to fight the pirates2014-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 20Using movie magic to fight the piratesSATURDAY FORM GUIDE WITH NEALA JOHNSON

WHEN school is out, the movies are in.

Nobody knows this better than Village Roadshow CEO Graham Burke, who admitted his company made "one hell of a mistake" delaying the Australian cinema release of The LEGO Movie until two months after the US - just for the school holidays. The delay caused the film to be pirated widely in Australia.

But Burke's comment shows the importance Australian distributors place on school holidays and films targeted at kids and families when it comes to doing big box office business.

The LEGO Movie was held for the prime Easter school holiday period and its $30 million gross is the biggest for any 2014 release so far.

But if not for the proliferation of illegal downloads, that gross would more likely sit in the $35-$40 million range.

Over the past three years, G and PG-rated films have, on average, accounted for more than 26 per cent of the total box office takings in Australia.

While not all G and PG films are specifically targeted at kids (oldies' favourite The Hundred-Foot Journey is one recent PG example), kids' titles do make up a good proportion of those films.

M-rated films (not recommended for children under 15) have also become a mainstay of the school holidays, especially given the surge of young-adult novel -adaptations in the wake of the Twilight and Hunger Games franchises.

Movies rated M which have successfully targeted school holiday windows this year include Divergent, Captain America: The Winter Soldier and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.

Ian Sutherland, Group Director of Marketing at the national chain Event Cinemas, said school holiday periods saw a flurry of kids' movies hit the cinemas.

"During one of the busiest periods of the year, families can frequent our cinemas multiple times, catching as many new-release flicks as time allow," he said.

In the past week, the most in-demand titles at the cinema have been teen-friendly fare: The Maze Runner, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and Into the Storm.

In the post-LEGO landscape, Village Roadshow has vowed to go day-and-date with US releases in future; and Burke believes fellow distributors 20th Century Fox and Universal will follow suit.

And whether this will mean Aussie kids can no longer -expect a flood of animation and adventure into cinemas every school holidays remains to be seen.

In the upcoming Christmas/New Year period the new -release movies will include: Paddington (yes, the bear); Annie; Big Hero 6; Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb; Penguins of Madagascar (a funny flick following the -successful Madagascar -series) and what will be an Aussie -favourite, Paper Planes, a 3D family drama film starring Sam Worthington and Anthony -LaPaglia.

BOXTROLLS (PG) This stop-motion animation is about a young orphan raised by sewer-dwelling trash collectors, as he tries to save his friends from an evil exterminator. The film is a strikingly animated production.

THE GIVER (M) The best aspects of this intriguing future-shock drama will go over the heads of kids under 10. But there's plenty of food-for-thought for the rest of the youth demographic. Rated M and now showing everywhere.

MAGIC (G) A loveable homeless cat sneaks into a mysterious mansion owned by retired magician Lawrence. The House of Magic, a beautifully rendered animation, is a cheery, quick-paced bundle of fun for the under-10 gang.

MAZE RUNNER (M) Dropped into a giant maze with other boys, Thomas learns he will have to team up with other "runners" to escape. The M-rating is fully warranted but for boys 10 and over, this gripping chase flick will be their must-see movie.

PLANES (G) Planes : Fire & Rescue is a a dramatic improvement upon a so-so original. When Dusty learns his engine is damaged and he may never race again, he joins a forest fire and rescue unit to be trained as a firefighter.

TARZAN (PG) The tale of a boy raised by apes, showing at Dendy, has been a family favourite for generations. This animated version sees Tarzan and Jane facing a mercenary army dispatched by the CEO of Greystoke Energies.

NINJA TURTLES The Turtles are back in Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles but this time not as family friendly with the M-rated combat scenes too violent and threatening for many children, coupled with sleazy asides by Turtles co-star Megan Fox.

BEARS (G) The Land Of The Bears is an animal documentary which gives an engaging and rare look into the lives of brown bears on Russia's Kamchatka peninsula. The 600kg stars of the show are a fascinating species. Great for the whole family.

GUARDIANS (M) Guardians of the Galaxy is a sci-fi adventure-comedy about group of reformed space criminals who work together to stop a fanatic from destroying the galaxy. Most scenes (save from an occasional explosion) are inside the all-ages zone.

SHARK 3DThe Great White Shark 3D nature documentary, showing at the IMAX Theatre in Darling Harbour, gives a breathtaking encounter with the predator we love to fear. Shot at Great White hotspots the world over.

urn:contentItem:4P0N-6DB0-TXN5-S34X-00000-00GAME REVIEW2002-02-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisDRIVEPg. 7GAME REVIEWOFF ROAD WIDE OPENBOB HALL

So far, no software developer has done for off-road vehicles what Gran Turismo has done for performance cars, so Infogrames' Off Road Wide Open is a welcome arrival. Though not in Gran Turismo's league, it's on the way there.

Like the better-developed titles, Off Road Wide Open has first-rate scenery and vehicle graphics. The Americana "garage" houses Jeep (1970 CJ-5 and 2001 Wrangler), Chevrolet (1975 K10 Blazer and 2001 Silverado ute), Dodge (2001 Durango and 2001 Ram 2500 ute), Ford (1966 Bronco and 2001 F150 ute) and a pair of Hummers (soft-top and wagon). The vehicles start out in basic form, with upgrades to "modified", "pro" and "unlimited" dependent upon success in the game.

Three venues are available: Moab National Park in Utah, Yosemite National Park in California, and one merely listed as Hawaii. They're well rendered, with unexpected treats such as a freshly extinguished Yosemite forest fire (complete with spot fires and plenty of smoke) and some freshly cooled - in part - lava next to an active volcano in Hawaii.

Sadly the realism seems to taper off - rapidly - about here. Driving physics are at times weird, going from the sort of response you'd expect from a big 4WD with some weight and a high centre of gravity to Gran Turismo-like grip in a matter of seconds. Vehicles return to the upright as easily as they roll, and perhaps, thankfully, there's no representation of damage, which would add more realism. Especially since the vehicles will handle 350-metre vertical drops with aplomb. Certainly more than a human spine can withstand.

Apart from the questionable physics, another considerable dislike is one more American-accented "CHECKPOINT!" shouted during races. It even sounds like the same voice heard in rival game Burnout!

Though not of simulation quality, there's enough depth of game-play in Off Road Wide Open to keep you entertained a while.

RATING: 7/10

PLATFORM: Sony PlayStation 2

RETAIL PRICE: $99.95

urn:contentItem:7XV5-MXW1-2RG7-21FR-00000-00Victoria 'tragically unprepared' for future bushfires2010-02-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisVictoria 'tragically unprepared' for future bushfiresSamantha Donovan

The Royal Commission into the Black Saturday disaster has heard Victoria remains dangerously unprepared to tackle major bushfires and there are not enough firefighters to meet fuel reduction targets.

The Australian Workers Union (AWU) told the commission that the Victorian Government had broken a 2004 promise to boost the number of firefighters protecting public land.

Lawyers acting for the Victorian Government did not challenge the union's claims.

Fuel reduction on public land in Victoria is one of the most contentious issues for the Royal Commission to consider.

Athol Hodgson, a forest fire expert and a former chief fire officer with what was once the Victorian Department of Conservation, was blunt in his assessment to the commission.

"The Government of Victoria with respect to public land management has allowed fuel levels to accumulate to levels that I believe are quite unnatural," he said.

"They've accumulated to the levels and got so dry in a period of drought that it became impossible to stop some fires unless you were standing beside them when they started.

"Those unnaturally high levels of fuel contributed significantly to the fact that people died in large numbers in a very short space of time."

The Commission heard today that the Victorian Department of Sustainability and Environment currently burns less than 2 per cent of Victorian forests to reduce fuels.

But its own corporate plan says a desirable target is two to three times that.

Mr Hodgson asked the commission to recommend that the state almost triple its fuel reduction burns and enshrine the targets in legislation so performance can be accurately assessed.

The AWU represents field staff and firefighters employed by state government departments.

The secretary of the Victorian branch, Cesar Melham, told the commission that the state is "tragically unprepared" for another Black Saturday.

He says the number of firefighters has fallen dramatically since the 1980s and 1990s.

"It's a huge difference ... the numbers [have] fallen from a shameful 257 to a 237 notwithstanding the government promise to increase this number," he said.

A part-time army

The current statistics of the Victorian Department of Sustainability and Environment put the number of firefighters at 3,000, but Mr Melham says the figures are misleading.

"It's fine to have all these good numbers, 365, but we need to really look at how many actual firefighters, how many field staff [there are]," he said.

"There's too many chiefs and less firefighters. You can't go and fight a war with a part-time army.

"You need fully trained professional firefighters to prepare us, and the resources are not there."

The department's secretary, Greg Wilson, acknowledged the department was reviewing its staffing levels.

"We've got staffing submissions before the Government that go to questions about resources into the future, which I'm unable to talk about from a cabinet and confidence point of view," he said.

"But we're certainly building our resources, building our capability and getting better at it.

"The Government will want to look at the findings of the commission and a whole range of other factors, I suspect, before it makes definitive decisions about resources in response to the proposals that we've put to them recently."

urn:contentItem:5D7N-2G31-JD3N-5174-00000-00Using movie magic to fight the pirates2014-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 26Using movie magic to fight the piratesNEALA JOHNSON

WHEN school is out, the movies are in.

Nobody knows this better than Village Roadshow CEO Graham Burke, who admitted his company made "one hell of a mistake" delaying the Australian cinema release of The LEGO Movie until two months after the US - just for the school holidays. The delay caused the film to be pirated widely in Australia.

But Burke's comment shows the importance Australian distributors place on school holidays and films targeted at kids and families when it comes to doing big box office business.

The LEGO Movie was held for the prime Easter school holiday period and its $30 million gross is the biggest for any 2014 release so far.

But if not for the proliferation of illegal downloads, that gross would more likely sit in the $35-$40 million range.

Over the past three years, G and PG-rated films have, on average, accounted for more than 26 per cent of the total box office takings in Australia.

While not all G and PG films are specifically targeted at kids (oldies' favourite The Hundred-Foot Journey is one recent PG example), kids' titles do make up a good proportion of those films.

M-rated films (not recommended for children under 15) have also become a mainstay of the school holidays, especially given the surge of young-adult novel adaptations in the wake of the Twilight and Hunger Games franchises.

Movies rated M which have successfully targeted school holiday windows this year include Divergent, Captain America: The Winter Soldier and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Ian Sutherland, Group Director of Marketing at the national chain Event Cinemas, said school holiday periods saw a flurry of kids' movies hit the cinemas.

"During one of the busiest periods of the year, families can frequent our cinemas multiple times, catching as many new-release flicks as time allow," he said.

In the past week, the most in-demand titles at the cinema have been teen-friendly fare: The Maze Runner, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and Into the Storm. In the post-LEGO landscape, Village Roadshow has vowed to go day-and-date with US releases in future; and Burke believes fellow distributors 20th Century Fox and Universal will follow suit.

And whether this will mean Aussie kids can no longer expect a flood of animation and adventure into cinemas every school holidays remains to be seen.

In the upcoming Christmas/ New Year period the new release movies will include: Paddington (yes, the bear); Annie; Big Hero 6; Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb; Penguins of Madagascar (a funny flick following the successful Madagascar series) and what will be an Aussie favourite, Paper Planes, a 3D family drama film starring Sam Worthington and Anthony LaPaglia.

GUARDIANS (M) Guardians of the Galaxy is a sci-fi adventure-comedy about group of reformed space criminals who work together to stop a fanatic from destroying the galaxy.

Most scenes (save from an occasional explosion) are inside the all-ages zone.

BOXTROLLS (PG) This stop-motion animation is about a young orphan raised by sewer-dwelling trash collectors, as he tries to save his friends from an evil exterminator. The film is a strikingly animated production.

THE GIVER (M) The best aspects of this intriguing future-shock drama will go over the heads of kids under 10. But there's plenty of foodfor- thought for the rest of the youth demographic. Rated M and now showing everywhere.

MAGIC (G) A loveable homeless cat sneaks into a mysterious mansion owned by retired magician Lawrence. The House of Magic, a beautifully rendered animation, is a cheery, quick-paced bundle of fun for the under-10 gang.

MAZE RUNNER Dropped into a giant maze with other boys, Thomas learns he will have to team up with other "runners" to escape. The M-rating is fully warranted but for boys 10 and over, this gripping chase flick will be their must-see movie.

PLANES (G) Planes : Fire & Rescue is a a dramatic improvement upon a so-so original. When Dusty learns his engine is damaged and he may never race again, he joins a forest fire and rescue unit to be trained as a firefighter.

TARZAN (PG) The tale of a boy raised by apes, showing at Dendy, has been a family favourite for generations. This animated version sees Tarzan and Jane facing a mercenary army dispatched by the CEO of Greystoke Energies.

NINJA TURTLES The Turtles are back in Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles but this time not as family friendly with the M-rated combat scenes too violent and threatening for many children, coupled with sleazy asides by Turtles co-star Megan Fox.

BEARS (G) The Land Of The Bears is an animal documentary which gives an engaging and rare look into the lives of brown bears on Russia's Kamchatka peninsula. The 600kg stars of the show are a fascinating species. Great for the whole family.

SHARK 3DThe Great White Shark 3D nature documentary, showing at the IMAX Theatre in Darling Harbour, gives a breathtaking encounter with the predator we love to fear. Shot at Great White hotspots the world over.

urn:contentItem:4580-5M60-0197-54MR-00000-00<published>1999-06-29T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:50:30Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LOCAL; Pg. 8</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Timber! Barnett fears fall</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>MATT  PRICE  * Analysis</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JUST when Richard Court thought the forest debate could not possibly get more complicated or controversial, up jumps his deputy, Colin Barnett.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Through his implicit criticism of the Government's position, and his public request to be put in charge of the logging issue, Barnett has lobbed a political petrol bomb on to the already blazing forest row.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> And his thoughts on politics beyond the millennium -- visions of Premier "Honest" Colin's lean team employing a kinder, gentler drugs policy, sans upper house -- will positively rile colleagues who don't share Barnett's vision of such a smooth succession.</p><p>Barnett's observations, though, are probably accurate.</p><p> The logging issue threatens to suffocate the Court Government and Barnett's offer to forge a solution should be considered seriously by the Premier.</p><p> Barnett wants to succeed Court, but realises the Coalition could lose the next election if the forest issue is not resolved. So Barnett's ambitions would be tied to his success on the forest issue -- a neat alignment of Coalition and self-interest.</p><p> Barnett has made numerous public pledges not to challenge the Premier, but his extraordinary candour in an interview with The Australian leaves him open to attack.</p><p> Barnett, though, speaks with the confidence of a man with the support of many Liberal colleagues and, importantly, Perth's tight-knit business community.</p><p> Court's deputy knows there will be rivals in the succession race which, if the Coalition manages to scrape over the line to win a third successive term, would begin in earnest on election night.</p><p> Court is no great friend, nor natural ally, of Barnett and, ironically, giving his deputy exactly what he wants might help sink his ambitions.</p><p> Eking out a compromise between the timber industry and conservationists appears a nigh impossible task. Giving Barnett the job might permanently cripple his succession hopes.</p><p> And if Barnett manages to extinguish the forest fire, he probably deserves to be the next premier.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier H11</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BEST OF PAY TV</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>ROBERT FIDGEON</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">COMEDY</p><p nitf:lede="true">Supernova</p><p nitf:lede="true">(9pm, Monday, UKTV)</p><p nitf:lede="true">Premiere. This six-part comedy stars UK comedian Rob Brydon (left) as English astronomer Dr Paul Hamilton, sent to Broken Hill to take up a position at the Royal Australian Observatory. The joint Australian/British co-production has its moments, but for the most part this fish-out-of-water comedy also feels dated. Kris McQuade, Kat Stewart and Tim Draxl co-star.</p><p>BIOGRAPHY</p><p>Bad Boys</p><p>(7.30pm, Monday-Friday, Biography Channel)</p><p>Premiere. Five-night special, detailing some of the more notorious "bad boys". The series kicks off with former US president Bill Clinton (left). Then comes Larry Flynt, Jack Nicholson, Nick Nolte and Mick Jagger. Labelled "the comeback kid" because of his ability to triumph over sex scandals and countless setbacks, the Bill Clinton story is a gem.</p><p>HISTORY</p><p>Revival: Saving Our History</p><p>(8.30pm, Wednesday, History Channel)</p><p>Premiere. Hosted by Steve Liebmann (left), this Australian production visits a number of restored buildings across Australia and examines their cultural and historical significance. The history of each building will be told from the point of view of its social and architectural significance. Restored properties featured include Luna Park's carousel and Ballarat's Her Majesty's Theatre.</p><p>REALITY</p><p>Rebel Billionaire</p><p>(7.30pm, Thursday, FOX8)</p><p>Pay premiere. Virgin boss Sir Richard Branson (left) leads 16 young entrepreneurs on a round-the-world reality competition. Sir Richard takes the would-be moguls to international destinations where they tackle challenges that help shape future billionaires. But unknown to the 16 young people they are competing for the biggest prize in reality TV history: the presidency of Virgin</p><p>Worldwide, plus $US1million.</p><p>LIFESTYLE</p><p>Home</p><p>(7.30pm, Wednesday, LifeStyle Channel)</p><p>Brendan Moar, Shannon Fricke and Peter Evans (left) continue their fresh and vibrant look at styling, home, gardens, cooking and casual entertainment. This series of Home recognises that Australia does not exist in a vacuum, but rather is open to influences from all over the world. As a result, the show travels to Japan, Spain, Denmark and Slovenia for some of the latest trends.</p><p>SPECIAL</p><p>Mythbusters</p><p>(10.30pm, Monday, Discovery Channel)</p><p>Hosts Adam Savage and Jamie Hyneman (left) use scientific experiments, special effects and Buster -- one very abused crash-test dummy -- to bust urban myths. This episode sees if an unsuspecting scuba diver can be sucked out of the water by a fire-fighting helicopter and end up in the middle of a forest fire, and if Hollywood's zany car stunts live up to their status. Top series that delivers plenty of entertainment.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5FHR-YJ51-JD3N-51NY-00000-00Letters to the Editor2015-03-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:50:30ZLexisNexisPg. 22Letters to the Editor

If you're on good thing, stick with it I thought Australians were all about giving someone a fair go. The NSW Coalition government has taken the state from the weakest to the strongest economy in four years. They must be doing something right ("Baird builds winning lead", 16/3).

Remember, he is leasing the poles and wires, not selling them. What's more the government retains 51 per cent ownership from day one. What a pity Neville Wran didn't lease the land between Strathfield and the City instead of selling it. We could have had a WestConnex for far less cost. Surely they deserve a second term.

Ian Neilson Killara

Grand Prix would be right up Clover's alley Thank you Tim Blair for the humorous start to my Monday morning as I envisage your proposed Formula One circuit should the Australian grand prix ever be held here in Sydney ("Turning Grand Prix into a demolition derby ... for all the right reasons", 16/3).

It brings tremendous joy thinking the course could start and finish right outside Lord Mayor Clover Moore's Redfern house - a better choice could not be made unless it was directly outside the head office of the Sydney Greens.

The roaring sound of high-revving engines and reeking fumes would no doubt send them into cardiac meltdown.

David Ingram Randwick

No truth in unions' poles and wires advertising A former advertising executive told me the other day, "If I'd told lies in my advertising days like these unions are telling right now, I would have been sued!" ("Unions' reckless punt backfires", 16/3) The Nationals are keeping the regional poles and wires (that's over 90 per cent of the state) in government hands, which really is protecting regional jobs. So what are the unions complaining about? They should be thanking them.

Also, if power prices more than doubled under the last Labor government, what makes the unions think prices will stay lower under a Labor government again?

Bruce Thompson Port Macquarie

Shortsighted to put our trust in private sector Brian Potts asks what's wrong with privatisation ("Letters, 16/3). In return I ask what business would provide vital resources such as water, electricity, if they couldn't do so at a profit?

What companies would provide employment for Australians if they could employ overseas staff at a fraction of the cost?

A government's sole role should be to reallocate resources to where they are needed if the private sector won't provide them.

The necessities of life shouldn't be provided at a profit but provided as necessary. That's something called society.

Soon we will have multinationals providing employment for everyone but Australians, which will mean no tax revenue and no expenditure.

How shortsighted are we?

Kevan Silver Helensburgh

The forgotten land to west of the mountains Mike Baird and Luke Foley, while you intend to spend hundreds of millions of dollars revamping the metropolitan area if elected, may I remind you NSW does not end at the top of the Blue Mountains.

You not have noticed there are two areas west of the mountains. They are called the Central West and the Far West of NSW.

Believe it or not there are people living in these areas, yet not once have you mentioned in your promises any funding to these areas.

No mention of any relief for our drought-affected farmers, or funding to repair some of our dodgy roads. Hospitals and education seem to come second best after the big city.

Your big ideas for more tunnels and bigger motorways to relieve congestion are targeted to the metropolitan area only.

Get business to come to the country instead of going overseas, and you will relieve the pressure you so much desire and create jobs in the western areas.

Alan Jones Forbes

Where were fans to witness Souths miracle?

The mean, lean Redfern machine was on full display on Sunday afternoon as the South Sydney Rabbitohs performed a second-half miracle to defeat the Sydney Roosters 32-26 ("Ruthless GI tears Chooks to shreds in thriller", 16/3).

Pity though that only 27,289 spectators turned up to watch an enthralling encounter at the 80,000 capacity ANZ Stadium.

Eric Palm Gympie, Qld

No one does it better than Jeremy the dinosaur "Clarkson's career faces extinction", says the headline (16/3). Well, let me say this. I have no knowledge of the incident that has sparked this forest fire of reporting on the Top Gear prophet, other than what the newspapers have so far reported.

But what I do know in regards to the man who calls himself a dinosaur is that Jeremy Clarkson has demonstrated to untold millions of men the absolute importance of keeping the "boy" in the man.

No one has perfected it quite the way he has, other than his two apostles, Richard Hammond and James May.

Clarkson also reminded the world not to take things too seriously, and that driving should be fun as well as an art form, and man and car should come together as one, and that we would be far better off without the cave loads of thought police trying to come up with yet another way to spoil our fun and fine us for doing so.

Jeremy, you may call yourself a dinosaur, but do the maths, my boy. Dinosaur shows are packing them in all over the world.

Kids of all ages, including those on aged pension cards like myself, are dying to get close to this, the rarest of cave-dwellers.

Take a bow, my man.Dave Burt Kingswood
